firstLine: Temple Restoration Resumed
rest: Now the prophets, Haggai and Zechariah the son of Iddo, prophesied to the Jews who were in Judah and in Jerusalem, in the name of the God of Israel who was over them.

firstLine: Darius’ Search for the Decree
rest: Then King Darius issued forth a decree, and they searched the house of the treasury of scrolls being stored in Babylonia.

firstLine: The Decree of Darius
rest: “Now then, Tattenai governor of the province Beyond the River, Shethar-bozenai, and your associates, the envoys who are in the province Beyond the River—keep far away from there.

firstLine: Temple is Dedicated and Completed
rest: Then Tattenai the governor of the province Beyond the River, Shethar-bozenai, and their associates consequently did with diligence what Darius the king ordered.

firstLine: The Celebration of Passover
rest: On the fourteenth day of the first month the returned exiles observed the Passover feast.

firstLine: Ezra’s Arrival and Work
rest: After these things during the reign of King Artaxerxes of Persia, Ezra the son of Seraiah, son of Azariah, son of Hilkiah,

firstLine: Artaxerxes’ Letter to Ezra
rest: This is the copy of the letter that King Artaxerxes gave to Ezra the priest, the scribe of the scroll of the words of the commands of Yahweh and his statutes for Israel:

firstLine: Family Heads Who Returned With Ezra
rest: These were the heads of their families and the register of those returnees from Babylonia who came up with me in the reign of King Artaxerxes:

firstLine: Servants for the Temple are Gathered
rest: I gathered them by the river that goes to Ahava and we camped there for three days. And I looked at the people and the priests, I found no one there from the sons of Levi.

firstLine: Ezra Proclaims a Fast
rest: I proclaimed a fast there at the river Ahava to humble ourselves before our God in order to seek from him a safe journey for us, our children, and our possessions.

firstLine: The Priests’ Gift for the Temple
rest: I set apart twelve of the official priests: Sherebiah, Hashabiah, and ten of their brothers with them.

firstLine: Return to Jerusalem
rest: On the twelfth day of the first month we set out from the river of Ahava to go to Jerusalem. The hand of our God was on us and he delivered us from the hand of the enemy and from ambushing on the way.

firstLine: Disdain Over Mixed Marriages
rest: After finishing these things the officials approached me saying, “The people of Israel, the priests, and the Levites have not separated from the people of the lands with their detestable things, and from the Canaanites, Hittites, Perizzites, Jebusites, Ammonites, Moabites, Egyptians, and Amorites.

firstLine: Ezra Prays
rest: At the evening offering I got up from my mourning posture and, with my garment and robe torn, I fell down on my knees and I spread out my palms to Yahweh my God

firstLine: The People Respond
rest: While Ezra was praying and confessing, weeping and throwing himself down before the house of God, a very great assembly of men, women, and children from Israel gathered to him. And the people wept bitterly.

firstLine: Foreign Wives and Children are Sent Away
rest: Ezra rose from before the house of God and went to the chamber of Jehohanan son of Eliashib. He did not eat food nor drink water because he was mourning over the sin of the exiles.

firstLine: Nehemiah’s Prayer for the People
rest:
The words of Nehemiah son of Hacaliah.
It happened in the month of Kislev, in the twentieth year, that I myself was in the citadel in Susa,

firstLine: Nehemiah Sent
rest: It happened in the month of Nisan, in the twentieth year of King Artaxerxes, when wine was before him, I carried the wine and gave it to the king. And I had never been sad before the king.

firstLine: Nehemiah Inspects the Walls and Decides to Restore Them
rest: I came to Jerusalem and was there for three days.

firstLine: Organization of the Work
rest: Then Eliashib the high priest and his brothers the priests arose and rebuilt the Sheep Gate. They consecrated it and erected its doors. They consecrated it up to the Tower of the Hundred and up to the Tower of Hananel.

firstLine: Opposition Begins
rest: Now it happened when Sanballat heard that we were building the wall, he became angry and greatly provoked, and he mocked the Jews.

firstLine: Opposition Stopped
rest: Now when Sanballat, Tobiah, the Arabs, the Ammonites, and the Ashdodites heard that the restoration of the walls of Jerusalem were going forward and the gaps were being closed, they were very angry.

firstLine: Nehemiah Deals with Strife
rest: Now there was a great cry of distress of the people and of their wives against their Jewish brothers.

firstLine: Nehemiah Denies His Allotment
rest: Moreover, from the appointed day I was made their governor in the land of Judah, from the twentieth year until the thirty-second year of King Artaxerxes—twelve years. My brothers and I did not eat the food allowance of the governor.

firstLine: Enemies Foiled
rest: Now when it was reported to Sanballat, Tobiah, Geshem the Arab, and to the rest of our enemies that I had built the wall and that no gap was left in it—though up to that time I had not erected doors in the gates—

firstLine: The Wall is Completed
rest: So the wall was finished on the twenty-fifth day of Elul, in fifty-two days.

firstLine: Lists of the Exiles Who Returned
rest: Then my God put into my heart to assemble the nobles, the prefects, and the people to be enrolled. I found the book of the genealogy of those who first came back, and I found this written upon it:

firstLine: Ezra Reads the Law to the People
rest: All of the people gathered as one to the public square before the Water Gate. They asked Ezra the scribe to bring the book of the law of Moses that Yahweh had commanded Israel.

firstLine: Festival of Booths
rest: On the second day the heads of the families of all the people, the priests, and the Levites gathered together to Ezra the scribe to study the words of the law.

firstLine: The Nation Confesses
rest: On the twenty-fourth day of this month the Israelites gathered in fasting, in sackcloths, and with soil on them.

firstLine: The Names of Those Who Signed the Covenant
rest: Upon the sealed documents: Nehemiah the governor, son of Hacaliah and Zedekiah;

firstLine: A Summary of the Covenant
rest: “The rest of the people, the priests, the Levites, the gatekeepers, the singers, the temple servants, and all who separated themselves from the peoples of the lands to observe the law of God—their wives, their sons, their daughters, and all who know and understand—

firstLine: The Leaders and Servants in Jerusalem
rest: Now the commanders of the people lived in Jerusalem, but the remainder of the people cast lots to bring one out of ten to live in the holy city of Jerusalem, the other nine’s place was in the other cities.

firstLine: Villages Outside of Jerusalem
rest: As for the villages in their territories, some from the descendants of Judah lived in Kiriath-Arba and its settlements, Dibon and its settlements, Jekabzeel and its settlements,

firstLine: The Leaders and Servants in Jerusalem
rest: These are the priests and the Levites who came up with Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel and Jeshua: Seraiah, Jeremiah, Ezra,

firstLine: Dedication of the Wall of Jerusalem
rest: At the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem they sought the Levites from all of their places in order to bring them to Jerusalem to do the dedication with joy, thanksgivings, song and cymbals, stringed instruments and lyres.

firstLine: Celebration at the Temple
rest: On that day men were appointed for the storehouse rooms, the offerings, the first fruits, and the tithes, in order to gather in them from the fields of the cities the requirements of the law for the priests and Levites; for the joy of Judah was upon the priests and Levites standing there.

firstLine: Israel Separates Itself
rest: On that day the book of Moses was read in the hearing of the people and it was found written in it that no Ammonite or Moabite should ever come into the assembly of God

firstLine: Nehemiah Brings Reform
rest: Before this, Eliashib the priest who was appointed over the chambers of the house of our God—the one related to Tobiah—

firstLine: Nehemiah Begins Sabbath Reforms
rest: In those days I saw in Judah people treading the wine press on the Sabbath, bringing in heaps of grain and loading them on donkeys along with wine, grapes and figs, and every kind of burden and bringing it all to Jerusalem on the day of the Sabbath. And I warned them at that time against selling food.

firstLine: Mixed Marriages are Condemned
rest: Also in those days I saw Jews who had married women of Ashdod, Ammon, and Moab.

firstLine: The King’s Banquets
rest: And it happened in the days of Ahasuerus, the Ahasuerus who reigned from India to Cush—over one hundred and twenty-seven provinces.

firstLine: Queen Vashti Refuses the King’s Request
rest: On the seventh day, when the heart of the king was merry with wine, he said to Mehuman, Biztha, Harbona, Bigtha, Abagtha, Zethar, and Carcas, seven of the eunuchs attending King Ahasuerus,

firstLine: Esther is Chosen Queen
rest: After these things, when the anger of King Ahasuerus subsided, he remembered Vashti and what she had done and what had been decreed against her.

firstLine: A Plot Against the King
rest: When the virgins were gathered a second time, Mordecai was sitting at the gate of the king.

firstLine: Haman is Promoted
rest: After these things King Ahasuerus promoted Haman son of Hammedatha the Agagite, and he exalted him and set his position above all the officials who were with him.

firstLine: Mordecai Tells Esther of Haman’s Plot
rest: Mordecai learned all that had been done and he tore his clothes and put on sackcloth and ashes. And he went through the middle of the city and cried out a loud and bitter cry;

firstLine: Esther’s Banquet
rest: And it happened, on the third day, and Esther put on royal clothes, and she stood in the inner courtyard of the king’s palace, opposite the king’s palace; the king was sitting on his royal throne in the throne room opposite the doorway of the palace.

firstLine: Mordecai is Honored
rest: During that night the king’s sleep escaped him, and he gave orders to bring the scroll of records and chronicles, and they were read before the king.

firstLine: Esther’s Banquet
rest: So the king and Haman went to dine with Queen Esther.

firstLine: Haman is Hanged
rest: The king rose in his anger from the banquet and went to the palace garden, and Haman stood to beg for his life from Queen Esther, for he realized that the king was determined to make an end to his life.

firstLine: Mordecai is Promoted
rest: On that day King Ahasuerus gave Queen Esther the house of Haman, the enemy of the Jews; and Mordecai came before the king, for Esther had told what he was to her.

firstLine: The Jews Destroy Their Enemies
rest: In the twelfth month, that is the month of Adar, on the thirteenth day, on which the edict of the king arrived and his law was enacted, on the day in which the enemies of the Jews had hoped to gain power over them but was overturned, and the Jews gained power against their enemies,

firstLine: The Feast of Purim
rest: Mordecai wrote down these things and he sent letters to all the Jews who were in all of the provinces of King Ahasuerus, both near and far,

firstLine: Title
rest: King Ahasuerus imposed forced labor on the land and islands of the sea.

firstLine: Job’s Character and Greatness
rest: There was a man in the land of Uz whose name was Job. That man was blameless and upright and God-fearing and turning away from evil.

firstLine: The Adversary’s Attack on Job’s Possessions
rest: And then there was one day when his sons and his daughters were eating and drinking wine in their firstborn brother’s house.

firstLine: The Adversary’s Attack on Job’s Person
rest: And then one day the sons of God came to present themselves before Yahweh, and Satan also came into their midst to present himself before Yahweh.

firstLine: Job’s Blameless Behavior
rest: So Satan went out from Yahweh’s presence, and he inflicted Job with loathsome skin sores from the sole of his foot up to the crown of his head.

firstLine: Job Regrets His Birth
rest: Afterward Job opened his mouth and cursed his day.

firstLine: “Let the day perish on which I was born,
rest: and the night that said, ‘A man-child is conceived.’

firstLine: Let that day become darkness;
rest:
may God not seek it from above,
nor may daylight shine on it.

firstLine: Let darkness and deep shadow claim it;
rest:
let clouds settle on it;
let them terrify it with the blackness of day.

firstLine: Let darkness seize that night;
rest:
let it not rejoice among the days of the year;
let it not enter among the number of the months.

firstLine: Look, let that night become barren;
rest: let a joyful song not enter it.

firstLine: Let those who curse the day curse it,
rest: those who are skilled at rousing Leviathan.

firstLine: Let the stars of its dawn be dark;
rest:
let it hope for light but there be none,
and let it not see the eyelids of dawn

firstLine: because it did not shut the doors of my mother’s womb,
rest: nor did it hide trouble from my eyes.

firstLine: Job Wishes He Had Died
rest:
“Why did I not die at birth?
Why did I not come forth from the womb and expire?

firstLine: Why did the knees receive me
rest: and the breasts, that I could suck?

firstLine: For now I would lie down, and I would be at peace;
rest: I would be asleep; then I would be at rest

firstLine: with kings and counselors of the earth,
rest: who rebuild  ruins for themselves,

firstLine: or with high officials who have gold,
rest: who fill up their houses with silver.

firstLine: Or why was I not hidden like a miscarriage,
rest: like infants who did not see the light?

firstLine: There the wicked cease from troubling,
rest: and there the weary are at rest;

firstLine: the prisoners are at ease together;
rest: they do not hear the oppressor’s voice.

firstLine: The small and the great are there,
rest: and the slave is free from his masters.

firstLine: Job Wishes He Might Die
rest:
“Why does he give light to one in misery
and life to those bitter of soul,

firstLine: who wait for death, but it does not come,
rest: and search for it more than for treasures,

firstLine: who rejoice exceedingly,
rest: and they are glad when they find the grave?

firstLine: Why does he give light to a man whose way is hidden,
rest: and God has fenced him in all around?

firstLine: For my sighing comes before my bread,
rest: and my groanings gush forth like water

firstLine: because the dread that I feel has come upon me,
rest: and what I feared befalls me.

firstLine: I am not at ease, and I am not at peace,
rest: and I do not have rest, thus turmoil has come.”

firstLine: Eliphaz’s First Response to Job
rest: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,

firstLine: “If someone would test a word with you, would you be offended?
rest: But who can refrain from speaking?

firstLine: Look, you have instructed many,
rest: and you have strengthened weak hands.

firstLine: Your words have raised up the one who stumbles,
rest: and you have strengthened knees giving way.

firstLine: But now it has come to you, and you are worn out;
rest: it touches you, and you are horrified.

firstLine: “Think now, who has perished who is innocent?
rest: Or where are the upright destroyed?

firstLine: Just as I have seen, plowers of mischief
rest: and sowers of trouble will reap it.

firstLine: By the breath of God they perish,
rest: and by the blast of his anger they come to an end.

firstLine: The roar of the lion and the voice of a lion in its prime,
rest: and the teeth of the young lions are broken.

firstLine: The lion is perishing without prey,
rest: and the lion’s whelps are scattered.

firstLine: “And a word came stealing to me,
rest: and my ear received the whisper from it.

firstLine: Amid troubling thoughts from night visions,
rest: at the falling of deep sleep on men,

firstLine: dread met me, and trembling,
rest: and it made many of my bones shake.

firstLine: And a spirit glided before my face;
rest: the hair of my flesh bristled.

firstLine: It stood still, but I could not recognize its appearance;
rest:
a form was before my eyes;
there was a hush, and I heard a voice:

firstLine: ‘Can a human being be more righteous than God,
rest: or can a man be more pure than his Maker?

firstLine: Look, he does not trust in his servants
rest: and he charges his angels with error.

firstLine: How much more dwellers in clay houses,
rest:
whose foundation is in the dust?
They are crushed like a moth.

firstLine: Between morning and evening they are destroyed;
rest: without anyone regarding it they perish forever.

firstLine: Eliphaz’s Response Continues
rest:
“Call now, is there anyone answering you?
And to which of the holy ones will you turn?

firstLine: For vexation will slay the fool,
rest: and jealousy will kill the simple.

firstLine: I have seen a fool taking root,
rest: but suddenly I cursed his dwelling.

firstLine: His children are far from deliverance,
rest:
and they are crushed in the gate,
and there is no deliverer—

firstLine: whose harvest the hungry eats,
rest:
and he takes it from behind the thorns;
and the thirsty pants after their wealth.

firstLine: Indeed, mischief does not come from the dust,
rest: and trouble does not sprout from the earth.

firstLine: But a human being is born to trouble,
rest: and they soar aloft like sparks.

firstLine: “But I myself will seek God,
rest: and to God I would commit my cause.

firstLine: He is doing great and unsearchable things,
rest: marvelous things without number—

firstLine: the one who is giving rain on the surface of the earth
rest: and is sending water on the surface of the fields,

firstLine: to set the lowly on high,
rest: and those mourning are lifted to safety.

firstLine: He is frustrating the devices of the crafty,
rest: and their hands do not achieve success.

firstLine: He is capturing the wise in their craftiness,
rest: and the schemes of the wily are rushed.

firstLine: In the daytime they meet with darkness,
rest: and they grope at noon as in the night.

firstLine: And he saves from the sword of their mouth,
rest: even the poor from the hand of the strong.

firstLine: So there is hope for the powerless,
rest: and wickedness shuts its mouth.

firstLine: “Look, happy is the human being whom God reproves;
rest: and you must not despise the discipline of Shaddai,

firstLine: for he himself wounds, but he binds up;
rest: he strikes, but his hands heal.

firstLine: From six troubles he will deliver you,
rest: and in seven evil shall not touch you.

firstLine: In famine he will redeem you from death,
rest: and in war from the power of the sword.

firstLine: From the scourge of the tongue you shall be hidden,
rest: and you shall not be afraid of destruction when it comes.

firstLine: At destruction and famine you shall laugh,
rest: and you shall not fear the wild animals of the earth.

firstLine: For your covenant will be with the stones of the field,
rest: and the wild animals of the field will be at peace with you.

firstLine: And you shall know that your tent is safe,
rest: and you will inspect your fold, and you shall not be missing anything.

firstLine: And you shall know that your offspring are many,
rest: and your descendants like the vegetation of the earth.

firstLine: You shall come in maturity to the grave,
rest: as the raising up of a stack of sheaves in its season.

firstLine: “Look, we have searched this out—it is true;
rest: hear it and know it yourself.”

firstLine: Job’s Second Speech: A Response to Eliphaz
rest: Then Job answered and said,

firstLine: “If only my vexation could be well weighed,
rest: and my calamity could be lifted up together with it in the balances,

firstLine: for then it would be heavier than the sand of the seas;
rest: therefore my words have been rash,

firstLine: for the arrows of Shaddai are in me;
rest:
my spirit drinks their poison;
the terrors of God are arrayed against me.

firstLine: Does the wild ass bray over grass,
rest: or the ox bellow over its fodder?

firstLine: Can tasteless food be eaten without salt,
rest: or is there taste in the white of a marshmallow plant?

firstLine: I refused to touch them;
rest: they are like food that will make me ill.

firstLine: “O that my request may come,
rest: and that God may grant my hope,

firstLine: that God would decide that he would crush me,
rest: that he would let loose his hand and kill me.

firstLine: But it will still be my consolation,
rest:
and I would recoil in unrelenting pain,
for I have not denied the words of the Holy One.

firstLine: Indeed, my help is not in me,
rest: and any success is driven from me.

firstLine: “Loyal love should come for the afflicted from his friend,
rest: even if he forsakes the fear of Shaddai.

firstLine: My companions are treacherous like a torrent-bed;
rest: like a streambed of wadis they flow away,

firstLine: which are growing dark because of ice upon them,
rest: it will pile up snow.

firstLine: In time they dry up, they disappear;
rest: when it is hot, they vanish from their place.

firstLine: The paths of their way wind around;
rest: they go up into the wasteland, and they perish.

firstLine: The caravans of Tema looked;
rest: the traveling merchants of Sheba hope for them.

firstLine: They are disappointed, because they trusted;
rest: they came here and they are confounded.

firstLine: “For now you have become such;
rest: you see terrors, and you fear.

firstLine: Is it because I have said, ‘Give to me,’
rest: or, ‘Offer a bribe for me from your wealth’?

firstLine: or, ‘Save me from the foe’s hand,’
rest: or, ‘Ransom me from the tyrants’ hand’?

firstLine: Teach me, and I myself will be silent;
rest: and make me understand how I have gone astray.

firstLine: Do you intend to reprove my words
rest: and consider the words of a desperate man as wind?

firstLine: Even over the orphan you would cast the lot,
rest: and you would bargain over your friend.

firstLine: “Therefore be prepared, turn to me,
rest: and I surely will not lie to your face.

firstLine: Please turn, let no injustice happen;
rest: indeed, turn, my righteousness is still intact.

firstLine: Job’s Second Speech: A Response to Eliphaz
rest:
“Does not a human being have hard service on earth?
And are not his days like the days of a laborer?

firstLine: Like a slave he longs for the shadow,
rest: and like a laborer he waits for his wages.

firstLine: So I had to inherit months of worthlessness,
rest: and nights of misery are apportioned to me.

firstLine: My body is clothed with maggots and clods of dust;
rest: my skin hardens, then it gives way again.

firstLine: “My days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle,
rest: and they come to an end without hope.

firstLine: Remember that my life is a breath;
rest: my eye will not return to see good.

firstLine: The eye of the one seeing me will not see me;
rest: your eyes are upon me, but I will be gone.

firstLine: A cloud vanishes, and it goes away,
rest: so he who goes down to Sheol will not come up.

firstLine: He does not return again to his house,
rest: and his place does not recognize him again.

firstLine: “Even I will not restrain my mouth;
rest:
I will speak in my spirit’s anguish;
I will complain in my inner self’s bitterness.

firstLine: Am I the sea, or a sea monster,
rest: that you set a guard over me?

firstLine: When I say, ‘My bed will comfort me,
rest: and my couch will ease my complaint,’

firstLine: then you terrify me with dreams,
rest: and with visions you terrify me.

firstLine: So my inner self will choose strangling—
rest: death more than my existence.

firstLine: I loathe my life; I would not live forever;
rest: depart from me, for my days are a breath.

firstLine: “What is a human being that you make him great
rest: and that you fix your mind on him,

firstLine: so that you visit him every morning,
rest: you test him every moment?

firstLine: And why do you not pardon my transgression
rest:
and take away my guilt?
For now I shall lie in the dust,
and you will seek me, but I will be no more.”

firstLine: Bildad’s First Response to Job
rest: Then Bildad the Shuhite answered and said,

firstLine: “How long will you say these things,
rest: and the words of your mouth be a mighty wind?

firstLine: Does God pervert justice,
rest: or Shaddai pervert righteousness?

firstLine: If your children sinned against him,
rest: then he sent them into the power of their transgression.

firstLine: If you yourself would seek God,
rest: then you would plead to Shaddai for grace.

firstLine: If you are pure and upright,
rest:
indeed, now he will rouse himself for you,
and he will restore your righteous abode.

firstLine: Though your beginning was small,
rest: your end will be very great.

firstLine: “Indeed, please inquire of former generations,
rest: and consider what their ancestors have found,

firstLine: for we are of yesterday, and we do not know,
rest: for our days on earth are a shadow.

firstLine: Will they themselves not teach you and tell you
rest: and utter words from their heart?

firstLine: While it is in its flower and is not plucked,
rest: yet it withers before all grass.

firstLine: So are the paths of all who forget God;
rest: and the hope of the godless will perish,

firstLine: whose confidence is cut off
rest: and whose trust is a spider’s house.

firstLine: He will lean himself against his house, but it will not stand;
rest: he will take hold of it, but it will not endure.

firstLine: He is thriving before the sun,
rest: and his plant shoots spread over his garden.

firstLine: His roots twine over a stone heap;
rest: he sees a house of stone.

firstLine: If he destroys him from his place,
rest: then it deceives him, saying, ‘I have never seen you.’

firstLine: Look, this is the joy of his way,
rest: and from dust others will spring up.

firstLine: “Look, God will not reject the blameless,
rest: and he will not uphold the hand of evildoers.

firstLine: Yet he will fill your mouth with laughter
rest: and your lips with a shout of joy.

firstLine: Those who hate you will be clothed with shame,
rest: and the tent of the wicked will be no more.”

firstLine: Job’s Third Speech: A Response to Bildad
rest: Then Job answered and said,

firstLine: “Truly I know that it is so,
rest: but how can a human being be just before God?

firstLine: If he wants to contend with him,
rest: he cannot answer him one time in a thousand.

firstLine: He is wise in heart and mighty in strength;
rest: who has resisted him and succeeded?

firstLine: “He is the one who moves mountains, and they do not know how,
rest: who overturns them in his anger.

firstLine: He is the one who shakes the earth from its place,
rest: and its pillars tremble.

firstLine: He is the one who commands the sun, and it does not rise,
rest: and he seals up the stars.

firstLine: He is the one who alone stretches out the heavens
rest: and who tramples on the waves of the sea.

firstLine: He is the one who made the Bear and Orion,
rest: the Pleiades and the constellations of the south.

firstLine: He is the one who does great things beyond understanding
rest: and marvelous things beyond number.

firstLine: “If he passes by me, I would not see him;
rest: and if he should move on, I would not recognize him.

firstLine: God will not turn back his anger;
rest: beneath him the helpers of Rahab bow.

firstLine: If I summon him, and he should answer me,
rest: I do not believe that he will listen to my voice—

firstLine: who crushes me with a tempest
rest: and multiplies my wounds without cause.

firstLine: He will not allow me to catch my breath;
rest: rather, he will fill me with bitterness.

firstLine: Even though I am righteous, my mouth will condemn me;
rest: even though I am blameless, yet it would pronounce me guilty.

firstLine: “I am blameless; I do not care about myself;
rest: I loathe my life.

firstLine: It is all one; therefore I say,
rest: ‘He destroys both the blameless and the wicked.’

firstLine: When the whip kills suddenly,
rest: he mocks at the despair of the innocent.

firstLine: The earth is given into the hand of the wicked;
rest:
he covers the face of its judge—
if it is not he, then who is it?

firstLine: “And my days are swifter than a runner;
rest: they flee away; they do not see good.

firstLine: They go by like papyrus skiffs,
rest: like an eagle swoops down on its prey.

firstLine: Though I say, ‘I will forget my complaint;
rest: I will change my expression, and I will rejoice,’

firstLine: I become afraid of all my sufferings;
rest: I know that you do not consider me innocent.

firstLine: If I shall be declared guilty,
rest: why then should I labor in vain?

firstLine: If I wash myself with soap,
rest: and I cleanse my hands with lye,

firstLine: then you plunge me into the slime pit,
rest: and my clothes abhor me.

firstLine: “For he is not a mortal like me that I can answer him,
rest: that we can come to trial together.

firstLine: There is no arbiter between us
rest: that he might lay his hand on both of us.

firstLine: May he remove his rod from me,
rest: and let his dread not terrify me;

firstLine: then I would speak and not fear him,
rest: for in myself I am not fearful.

firstLine: Job Continues His Response to Bildad
I will say to God, ‘You should not condemn me;
rest: let me know why you contend against me.

firstLine: Is it good for you that you oppress,
rest:
that you despise the labor of your hands,
and you smile over the schemes of the wicked?

firstLine: Are your days as the days of human beings,
rest: or your years as the days of man,

firstLine: that you seek out my iniquity,
rest: and you search for my sin

firstLine: because of your knowledge that I am not guilty,
rest: and there is no escaping from your hand?

firstLine: Your hands fashioned me and made me altogether,
rest: then you destroyed me.

firstLine: Please remember that you made me like clay,
rest: but you turn me into dust again?

firstLine: Did you not pour me out like milk
rest: and curdle me like cheese?

firstLine: You clothed me with skin and flesh,
rest: and you knit me together with bones and sinews.

firstLine: You have granted me life and loyal love,
rest: and your care has preserved my spirit.

firstLine: “‘Yet you hid these things in your heart;
rest: I know that this was your purpose.

firstLine: If I had sinned, then you would be watching me,
rest: and you would not acquit me of my guilt.

firstLine: And if my head grows bold, you would hunt me as the lion in its prime;
rest: and you repeat your exploits against me.

firstLine: You renew your witnesses against me,
rest:
and you increase your vexation against me;
relief forces are against me.

firstLine: I should have been as though I had not been;
rest: I should have been brought from the womb to the grave.

firstLine: Before I go—and I will not return—
rest: to the land of darkness and deep shadow,

firstLine: to the land of darkness,
rest:
like the darkness of a deep shadow and chaos,
so that it shines forth like darkness.’”

firstLine: Zophar’s First Response to Job
rest: Then Zophar the Naamathite answered and said,

firstLine: “Should an abundance of words go unanswered,
rest: or a man full of talk be vindicated?

firstLine: For you say, ‘My teaching is pure,
rest: and I am clean in your sight.’

firstLine: But, O that God might speak,
rest: and that he would open his lips to you,

firstLine: and that he would tell you the secrets of wisdom,
rest:
for insight has many sides.
And know that God on your behalf has forgotten some of your guilt.

firstLine: “Can you find out the essence of God,
rest: or can you find out the ultimate limits of Shaddai?

firstLine: Its measure is longer than the earth
rest: and broader than the sea.

firstLine: “If he passes through and imprisons someone
rest: and summons the assembly, then who can hinder him?

firstLine: For he knows those who are worthless;
rest: when he sees iniquity, he will not consider it.

firstLine: But an empty-headed person will get understanding
rest: when a wild donkey’s colt is born as a human being.

firstLine: “If you yourself direct your heart
rest: and stretch out your hands to him—

firstLine: if iniquity is in your hand, put it far away,
rest: and you must not let wickedness reside in your tents—

firstLine: surely then you will lift up your face without blemish,
rest: and you will be firmly established and will not fear.

firstLine: For you yourself will forget your misery;
rest: you will remember it as water that has flowed past.

firstLine: “And your life will be brighter than noon;
rest: its darkness will be like the morning.

firstLine: And you will have confidence because there is hope;
rest: and you will be well protected—you will sleep in safety.

firstLine: And you will lie down, and no one will make you afraid;
rest: and many will entreat your favor.

firstLine: But the eyes of the wicked will fail;
rest:
and refuge will be lost to them,
and their hope is to breathe their last breath.”

firstLine: Job’s Fourth Speech
rest: Then Job answered and said,

firstLine: “Truly indeed you are the people,
rest: and wisdom will die with you.

firstLine: I also have insight like you;
rest:
I am not more inferior than you.
And who does not know things like these?

firstLine: I am a laughingstock to my friends:
rest:
‘He calls on God, and he answers him.’
A righteous, blameless man is a laughingstock.

firstLine: Those at ease have contempt for the thought of disaster,
rest: but it is ready for those unstable of foot.

firstLine: The tents of the destroyers are at peace,
rest:
and there is security for those who provoke God,
for those whom God brings into his hand.

firstLine: “But ask the animals, and they will teach you,
rest: and the birds of the heaven, and they will tell you;

firstLine: or ask the earth, and it will teach you,
rest: and the fishes of the sea will declare to you.

firstLine: Who among all of these does not know
rest: that Yahweh’s hand has done this?

firstLine: In whose hand is the life of all living things
rest: and the breath of every human being?

firstLine: Does not the ear test words
rest: and the palate taste food for itself?

firstLine: Wisdom is with the aged,
rest: and understanding is in length of days.

firstLine: “With him are wisdom and powerful deeds,
rest: and to him belong counsel and understanding.

firstLine: If he tears down, then it will not be rebuilt;
rest: if he shuts a man in, then he cannot be freed.

firstLine: Look, if he withholds the water, then they dry up;
rest: and if he sends them out, then they overwhelm the land.

firstLine: “Strength and sound wisdom are with him;
rest: the deceived and the deceiver are his.

firstLine: He leads counselors away stripped,
rest: and he makes fools of judges.

firstLine: He loosens the fetters of kings,
rest: and he binds a loincloth on their loins.

firstLine: He leads priests away stripped,
rest: and he overthrows the members of ancient families.

firstLine: He deprives the trustworthy of speech,
rest: and he takes away the discretion of elders.

firstLine: He pours contempt on noblemen,
rest: and he loosens the girdle of the mighty.

firstLine: “He uncovers mysteries out of darkness,
rest: and he brings deep shadow to the light.

firstLine: He makes the nations great, then he destroys them;
rest: he expands the nations, then he guides them.

firstLine: He strips away the insight of the heads of the earth’s people,
rest: and he makes them wander in a pathless wasteland.

firstLine: They grope in the dark without light,
rest: and he makes them stagger like a drunkard.

firstLine: Job’s Fourth Speech Continues
rest:
“Look, my eye has seen everything;
my ear has heard and has understood it.

firstLine: What you know, I myself also know—
rest: I am not more inferior than you.

firstLine: But I would speak to Shaddai,
rest: and I desire to argue with God.

firstLine: “But you whitewash with lies;
rest: all of you are worthless healers.

firstLine: O that you would keep completely silent,
rest: and that it would become wisdom for you.

firstLine: Please hear my argument,
rest: and listen attentively to the pleadings of my lips.

firstLine: “Will you speak falsely for God?
rest: And will you speak deceitfully for him?

firstLine: “Surely he will rebuke you
rest: if you show partiality in secret.

firstLine: Will not his majesty terrify you,
rest: and his dread fall upon you?

firstLine: Your maxims are proverbs of ashes;
rest: your defenses are defenses of clay.

firstLine: “Let me have silence, and I myself will speak,
rest: and let come over me whatever may.

firstLine: Why should I take my flesh in my teeth
rest: and put my life in my hand?

firstLine: Look, though he kill me, I will hope in him;
rest: however, I will defend my ways before him.

firstLine: Moreover, this is salvation to me,
rest: that the godless would not come before him.

firstLine: “Listen carefully to my words,
rest: and let my exposition be in your ears.

firstLine: Please look, I have prepared my case;
rest: I know that I myself will be vindicated.

firstLine: Job Argues His Case with God
rest:
“Only you must not do these two things to me;
then I will not hide from your face:

firstLine: withdraw your hand from me,
rest: and let not your dread terrify me.

firstLine: Then call, and I myself will answer;
rest: or let me speak, then reply to me.

firstLine: “How many are my iniquities and sins?
rest: Make known to me my transgression and my sin.

firstLine: Why do you hide your face
rest: and count me as your enemy?

firstLine: “Indeed, you write bitter things against me,
rest: and you make me reap the iniquities of my childhood.

firstLine: And you put my feet in the block,
rest:
and you watch all my paths;
you carve a mark on the soles of my feet.

firstLine: And he himself wastes away like something rotten,
rest: like a garment that the moth has eaten.

firstLine: Job Continues to Argue His Case with God
rest:
“A human being born of a woman
is short of days and full of troubles.

firstLine: Like a flower he comes up, and he withers away;
rest: and he flees like a shadow, but he does not last.

firstLine: Even on such a one you fix your eyes,
rest: and you bring me into judgment with you.

firstLine: “Who can bring a clean thing from an unclean thing?
rest: No one!

firstLine: If his days are determined, the number of his months is with you;
rest: you have appointed his boundaries, and he cannot cross them.

firstLine: Look away from him, and let him desist
rest: until he enjoys his days like a laborer.

firstLine: “Indeed, there is hope for a tree:
rest:
if it is cut down, then it will sprout again,
and its new shoots will not cease;

firstLine: though its root grows old in the earth,
rest: and its stump dies in the dust,

firstLine: at the scent of water it will bud,
rest: and it will put forth branches like a young plant.

firstLine: “But a man dies, and he dwindles away;
rest: thus a human being passes away, and where is he?

firstLine: As water disappears from a lake,
rest: and a river withers away and dries up,

firstLine: “O that you would conceal me in Sheol,
rest:
that you would hide me until your wrath is past,
that you would appoint a set time for me and remember me.

firstLine: You would call, and I myself would answer you;
rest: you would long for the work of your hand.

firstLine: For then you would count my steps,
rest: but you would not keep watch over my sin.

firstLine: My transgression would be sealed in a bag,
rest: and you would cover over my guilt.

firstLine: “But a mountain falls; it crumbles away,
rest: and a rock moves away from its place.

firstLine: Water wears away stones;
rest:
its torrents wash away the soil of the earth;
so you destroy the hope of human beings.

firstLine: You overpower him forever, and he passes away;
rest: you change his countenance, then you send him away.

firstLine: His children may come to honor, but he does not know it;
rest: or they may become lowly, but he does not realize it.

firstLine: He feels only the pain of his own body,
rest: and his inner self mourns for him.”

firstLine: Eliphaz’s Second Response to Job
rest: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,

firstLine: “Should the wise answer with windy knowledge,
rest: and should he fill his stomach with the east wind?

firstLine: Should he argue in talk that is not profitable
rest: or in words with which he cannot do good?

firstLine: “What is worse, you yourself are doing away with fear,
rest: and you are lessening meditation before God.

firstLine: For your iniquity teaches your mouth,
rest: and you choose the tongue of the crafty.

firstLine: Your mouth condemns you, and not I;
rest: and your lips testify against you.

firstLine: “Were you born the firstborn of the human race?
rest: And were you brought forth before the hills?

firstLine: Both the gray-haired and the old are among us—
rest: those older than your father.

firstLine: “Are the consolations of God too small for you,
rest: a word spoken gently with you?

firstLine: that you turn your spirit against God,
rest: and you let such words go out of your mouth?

firstLine: “What is a human being, that he can be clean,
rest: or that one born of a woman can be righteous?

firstLine: Look, he does not trust his holy ones,
rest: and the heavens are not clean in his eyes.

firstLine: How much less he who is abominable and corrupt,
rest: a man drinking wickedness like water.

firstLine: “I will show you, listen to me;
rest: and what I have seen, I will tell—

firstLine: what wise men have told,
rest: and they have not hidden that which is from their ancestors,

firstLine: to whom alone the land was given,
rest: and no stranger passed through their midst.

firstLine: “All of the wicked one’s days he is writhing,
rest: even through the number of years that are laid up for the tyrant.

firstLine: Sounds of terror are in his ears;
rest: in prosperity the destroyer will come against him.

firstLine: He cannot trust that he will return from darkness,
rest: and he himself is destined for the sword.

firstLine: “He is wandering for bread, saying, ‘Where is it?’
rest: He knows that a day of darkness is ready at hand.

firstLine: Anguish and distress terrify him;
rest: they overpower him like a king ready for the battle.

firstLine: Because he stretched out his hand against God,
rest: and he was arrogant to Shaddai;

firstLine: he stubbornly runs against him
rest: with his thick-bossed shield.

firstLine: “Because he has covered his face with his fat
rest: and has gathered fat upon his loins,

firstLine: he will dwell in desolate cities,
rest:
in houses that they should not inhabit,
which are destined for rubble.

firstLine: He will not become rich, and his wealth will not endure,
rest: and their possessions will not stretch across the earth.

firstLine: “He will not escape from darkness;
rest:
a flame will dry up his new shoot,
and by the wind of his mouth he shall be removed.

firstLine: Let him not trust in emptiness—he will be deceiving himself—
rest: for worthlessness will be his recompense.

firstLine: It will be paid in full before his time,
rest: and his branch will not flourish.

firstLine: “He will shake off his unripe fruit like the vine,
rest: and he will cast off his blossom like the olive tree;

firstLine: for the company of the godless is barren,
rest: and fire consumes the tents of those who accept bribes.

firstLine: They conceive trouble and bring forth mischief,
rest: and their womb prepares deceit.”

firstLine: Job’s Fifth Speech
rest: Then Job answered and said,

firstLine: “I have heard many things like these;
rest: all of you are miserable comforters.

firstLine: I myself also could talk as you,
I could encourage you with my mouth,
rest: and the solace of my lips would ease the pain.

firstLine: If I speak, my pain is not relieved;
rest: and if I cease, how much will leave me?

firstLine: “Surely now he has worn me out;
rest: you have devastated all my company.

firstLine: Thus you shriveled me up;
His wrath has torn, and he has been hostile toward me;
rest:
he gnashed at me with his teeth.
My foe sharpens his eyes against me.

firstLine: They gaped at me with their mouth;
rest:
they struck my cheeks with disgrace;
they have massed themselves together against me.

firstLine: God delivers me to an evil one,
rest: and he casts me into the hands of the wicked.

firstLine: “I was at ease, then he broke me in two,
His archers surround me;
rest:
he slashes open my kidneys, and he does not have compassion;
he pours out my gall on the ground.

firstLine: He breached me breach upon breach;
rest: he rushes at me like a warrior.

firstLine: “I have sewed sackcloth on my skin,
rest: and I have inserted my pride in the dust.

firstLine: My face is red because of weeping,
rest: and deep shadows are on my eyelids,

firstLine: although violence is not on my hands,
rest: and my prayer is pure.

firstLine: “O earth, you should not cover my blood,
rest: and let there be no place for my cry for help.

firstLine: So now look, my witness is in the heavens,
rest: and he who vouches for me is in the heights.

firstLine: My friends scorn me;
rest: my eye pours out tears to God,

firstLine: and it argues for a mortal with God,
rest: and as a human for his friend.

firstLine: Indeed, after a few years have come,
rest: then I will go the way from which I will not return.

firstLine: Job’s Fifth Speech, Continued
rest:
“My spirit is pulled down; my days are extinguished;
the graveyard is for me.

firstLine: Surely mockery is with me,
rest: and my eye rests on their provocation.

firstLine: Please lay down a pledge for me with yourself;
rest: who is he who will give security for my hand?

firstLine: Indeed, you have closed their mind from understanding;
rest: therefore, you will not let them triumph.

firstLine: He denounces friends for reward,
rest: so his children’s eyes will fail.

firstLine: “And he has made me a proverb for the peoples,
rest: and I am one before whom people spit.

firstLine: And my eye has grown dim from grief,
rest: and the limbs of my body are all like a shadow.

firstLine: The upright are appalled at this,
rest: and the innocent excites himself over the godless.

firstLine: But the righteous holds on to his way,
rest: and he who has clean hands increases in strength.

firstLine: “My days are past; my plans are broken down—
rest: even the desires of my heart.

firstLine: They make night into day,
rest: saying, ‘Light is near to darkness.’

firstLine: If I hope for Sheol as my house,
rest: if I spread my couch in the darkness,

firstLine: if I call to the pit, ‘You are my father,’
rest: to the maggot, ‘You are my mother or my sister,’

firstLine: Bildad’s Second Speech
rest: Then Bildad the Shuhite answered and said,

firstLine: “How long will you hunt for words?
rest: Consider, and afterward we shall speak.

firstLine: “You who are tearing yourself in your anger,
rest:
will the earth be forsaken because of you?
Or will the rock be removed from its place?

firstLine: Furthermore, the light of the wicked is put out,
rest: and the flame of his fire will not shine.

firstLine: The light becomes dark in his tent,
rest: and his lamp above him is put out.

firstLine: “His strong steps are shortened,
rest: and his own schemes throw him down,

firstLine: for he is thrust into a net by his feet,
rest: and he walks into a pitfall.

firstLine: A trap seizes him by the heel;
rest: a snare takes hold of him.

firstLine: His rope is hidden in the ground,
rest: and his trap on the path.

firstLine: “Sudden terrors terrify him all around,
rest: and they chase him at his heels.

firstLine: His wealth will become hunger,
rest: and disaster is ready for his stumbling.

firstLine: It consumes parts of his skin;
rest: the firstborn of death consumes his limbs.

firstLine: He is torn from his tent in which he trusted,
rest: and it brought him to the king of terrors.

firstLine: “Nothing remains for him in his tent;
rest: sulfur is scattered upon his dwelling place.

firstLine: His roots dry up below,
rest: and its branches wither away above.

firstLine: His remembrance perishes from the earth,
rest: and there is not a name for him on the street.

firstLine: “They thrust him from light into darkness,
rest: and they drive him out from the world.

firstLine: There is no offspring for him nor a descendant among his people,
rest: and there is not a survivor in his abode.

firstLine: Those of the west are appalled over his fate,
rest: and those of the east are seized with horror.

firstLine: Surely these are the dwellings of the godless,
rest: and this is the dwelling place of him who knows not God.”

firstLine: Job’s Sixth Speech: A Response to Bildad
rest: Then Job answered and said,

firstLine: “How long will you torment me
rest: and crush me with words?

firstLine: These ten times you have disgraced me;
rest: you are not ashamed that you have attacked me.

firstLine: And what is more, if I have truly erred,
rest: my error remains with me.

firstLine: If indeed you must magnify yourselves against me,
rest: and you must let my disgrace argue against me,

firstLine: know then that God has wronged me
rest: and has surrounded me with his net.

firstLine: “Look, I cry out, ‘Violence!’ but I am not answered;
rest: I cry out, but there is no justice.

firstLine: He has walled up my way so that I cannot pass;
rest: and he has set darkness upon my paths.

firstLine: He has taken my glory from me,
rest: and he has removed the crown of my head.

firstLine: and he has kindled his wrath against me,
rest: and he has counted me as one of his foes.

firstLine: His troops have come together
rest:
and have thrown up their rampart against me
and have encamped around my tent.

firstLine: “He has removed my kinsfolk from me,
rest: and my acquaintances have only turned aside from me.

firstLine: My relatives have failed,
rest: and my close friends have forgotten me.

firstLine: The sojourners in my house and my slave women count me as a stranger;
rest: I have become a foreigner in their eyes.

firstLine: I call to my servant, but he does not answer;
rest: I must personally plead with him.

firstLine: My breath is repulsive to my wife,
rest: and I am loathsome to my own family.

firstLine: Little boys also despise me;
rest: when I rise, then they talk against me.

firstLine: All my intimate friends abhor me,
rest: and these whom I have loved have turned against me.

firstLine: My bones cling to my skin and to my flesh,
rest: and I have escaped by the skin of my teeth.

firstLine: “Pity me, pity me, you my friends,
rest: for God’s hand has touched me.

firstLine: “O that my words could be written down!
rest: O that they could be inscribed in a scroll!

firstLine: That with a pen of iron and with lead
rest: they might be engraved on a rock forever!

firstLine: But I myself know that my redeemer is alive,
rest: and at the last he will stand up upon the earth.

firstLine: And after my skin has been thus destroyed,
rest: but from my flesh I will see God,

firstLine: whom I will see for myself,
rest:
and whom my eyes will see and not a stranger.
My heart faints within me.

firstLine: “If you say, ‘How will we persecute him?’
rest: And ‘The root of the trouble is found’ in me,

firstLine: be afraid for yourselves because of the sword,
rest:
for wrath brings punishment by the sword,
so that you may know that there is judgment.”

firstLine: Zophar’s Second Speech
rest: Then Zophar the Naamathite answered and said,

firstLine: “Therefore my disquieting thoughts bring me back
rest: for the sake of my inward excitement.

firstLine: I hear discipline that insults me,
rest: and a spirit beyond my understanding answers me.

firstLine: “Did you know this from of old,
rest: since the setting of the human being on earth,

firstLine: that the rejoicing of the wicked is short,
rest: and the joy of the godless lasts only a moment?

firstLine: Even though his stature mounts up to the heaven,
rest: and his head reaches to the clouds,

firstLine: he will perish forever like his dung;
rest: those who have seen him will say, ‘Where is he?’

firstLine: He will fly away like a dream, and they will not find him,
rest: and he will be chased away like a vision of the night.

firstLine: The eye that saw him will not see him again,
rest: and his place will no longer behold him.

firstLine: His children will seek favors from the poor,
rest: and his hands will return his wealth.

firstLine: His bones were full of his vigor,
rest: but it will lie down with him on the dust.

firstLine: “Though wickedness tastes sweet in his mouth,
rest: and he hides it under his tongue,

firstLine: though he spares it and does not let it go
rest: and holds it back in the midst of his palate,

firstLine: in his bowels his food is turned,
rest: the venom of horned vipers is within him.

firstLine: He swallows riches, but he vomits them up;
rest: God drives them out from his stomach.

firstLine: He will suck the poison of horned vipers;
rest: the viper’s tongue will kill him.

firstLine: He will not enjoy the streams,
rest: the torrents of honey and curds.

firstLine: Returning the products of his toil, he will not swallow;
rest: according to the profit of his trade, he will not enjoy,

firstLine: for he has oppressed; he has abandoned the poor;
rest: he has seized a house but did not build it.

firstLine: Because he has not known satisfaction in his stomach,
rest: he lets nothing escape that he desires.

firstLine: There is nothing left after he has eaten;
rest: therefore his prosperity will not endure.

firstLine: In the fullness of his excess he will be in distress;
rest: all of misery’s power will come upon him.

firstLine: When his stomach fills up, God will send his burning anger upon him,
rest: and he will let it rain down upon him as his food.

firstLine: “He will flee from an iron weapon,
rest: but an arrow of bronze will pierce him.

firstLine: He draws it forth, and it comes out from his body,
rest:
and the glittering point comes from his gall-bladder;
terrors come upon him.

firstLine: Total darkness is hidden for his treasures;
rest:
an unfanned fire will devour him;
the remnant will be consumed in his tent.

firstLine: The heavens will reveal his guilt,
rest: and the earth will rise up against him.

firstLine: The products of his house will be carried away
rest: like gushing waters on the day of his wrath.

firstLine: This is a wicked human being’s portion from God
rest: and the inheritance of his decree from God.”

firstLine: Job’s Seventh Speech: A Response to Zophar
rest: Then Job answered and said,

firstLine: “Listen carefully to my words,
rest: and let this be your consolation.

firstLine: Bear with me, and I myself will speak;
rest: then after my speaking you can mock.

firstLine: Turn to me and be appalled,
rest: and place your hand on your mouth.

firstLine: And when I think of it, I am horrified,
rest: and shuddering seizes my flesh.

firstLine: “Why do the wicked live,
rest: grow old, even grow mighty in power?

firstLine: With them their offspring are established before them,
rest: and their descendants before their eyes.

firstLine: Their houses are safe without fear,
rest: and the rod of God is not upon them.

firstLine: His bull breeds and does not fail;
rest: his cow calves and does not miscarry.

firstLine: They send out their little ones like the flock,
rest: and their children dance around.

firstLine: They sing to the tambourine and lyre,
rest: and they rejoice to the sound of the long flute.

firstLine: They spend their days in prosperity,
rest: and in peace they go down to Sheol.

firstLine: And they say to God, ‘Turn away from us,
rest: for we do not desire to know your ways.

firstLine: Who is Shaddai that we should serve him,
rest: or what would we benefit when we plead with him?’

firstLine: Look, their prosperity is not in their hands;
rest: the schemes of the wicked are repugnant to me.

firstLine: “How often is the lamp of the wicked put out,
rest:
and their disaster comes upon them?
He distributes pains in his anger.

firstLine: How often are they like straw before the wind,
rest: and like chaff that the storm carries away?

firstLine: ‘God stores up his iniquity for his children’?
rest: Then let him repay it to him that he may know.

firstLine: Let his eyes see his decay,
rest: and let him drink from the wrath of Shaddai,

firstLine: for what does he care for his house after him,
rest: when the number of his months is cut off?

firstLine: Can anyone teach knowledge to God,
rest: since he himself judges high ones?

firstLine: This one dies in full prosperity,
rest: completely at ease and secure.

firstLine: His vats are full with milk
rest: and the marrow of his bones is moist.

firstLine: Yet another dies with a bitter inner self
rest: and has not tasted prosperity.

firstLine: They lie down together in the dust,
rest: and maggots cover them.

firstLine: “Look, I know your thoughts
rest: and the schemes you devise against me.

firstLine: For you say, ‘Where is the nobleman’s house,
rest: and where are the tents in which the wicked dwell?’

firstLine: Do you not ask those traveling the roads,
rest: and do you not take notice of their accounts?

firstLine: Indeed, the wicked is spared from the day of disaster;
rest: he is delivered from the day of wrath.

firstLine: When he is brought to the grave,
rest: then someone stands guard over the tomb.

firstLine: The clods of the valley are sweet to him;
rest:
everyone will follow after him,
and before him they are innumerable.

firstLine: So how will you comfort me with emptiness,
rest: when fraud is left in your answers?”

firstLine: Eliphaz’s Third Speech
rest: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,

firstLine: “Can a man be of use to God?
rest: Yes, can the wise be of use to him?

firstLine: Is it a pleasure to Shaddai if you are righteous,
rest: or a gain if you make your ways blameless?

firstLine: Does he reprove you because of your reverence
rest: or enter into judgment with you?

firstLine: Is not your wickedness great,
rest: and there is no end to your iniquities?

firstLine: “Indeed, you have required a pledge from your family for nothing,
rest: and you have stripped off the clothes of the naked.

firstLine: You have given no water for the weary to drink,
rest: and you withheld food from the hungry.

firstLine: And the land belongs to the man of power,
rest: and the favored lives in it.

firstLine: You have sent widows away empty-handed,
rest: and the arms of orphans were crushed.

firstLine: Therefore trapping nets are all around you,
rest: and panic suddenly terrifies you,

firstLine: or it is so dark you cannot see,
rest: and a flood of water covers you.

firstLine: “Is not God in the height of the heavens?
rest: But see how lofty are the highest stars.

firstLine: Thick clouds are a covering for him, so that he does not see;
rest: and he walks about on the dome of heaven.’

firstLine: Will you keep to the way of old
rest: that the people of mischief have trod,

firstLine: who were snatched away before their time,
rest: whose foundation was washed away by a current?

firstLine: Those who said to God, ‘Turn away from us,’
rest: and ‘What can Shaddai do to us?’

firstLine: Yet he himself filled up their houses with good things,
rest: but the schemes of the wicked are repugnant to me.

firstLine: The righteous see, and they rejoice,
rest: but the innocent one mocks at them.

firstLine: Surely our foe perishes,
rest: and fire has consumed their remainder.

firstLine: “Please reconcile yourself with him,
rest: and be at peace; in this way, good will come to you.

firstLine: Please receive instruction from his mouth,
rest: and place his words in your heart.

firstLine: If you return to Shaddai, you will be restored;
rest: if you remove wickedness from your tent,

firstLine: and if you put gold ore in the dust,
rest: and the gold of Ophir in the rock of wadis,

firstLine: then Shaddai will be your gold ore
rest: and your precious silver.

firstLine: Indeed, then you will delight yourself in Shaddai,
rest: and you will expect that God will be good to you.

firstLine: You will pray to him, and he will hear you,
rest: and you will pay your vows.

firstLine: And you will decide on a matter, and it will be established for you,
rest: and light will shine on your ways.

firstLine: When they are humiliated, you say, ‘It is pride,’
rest: for he saves the humble.

firstLine: He will deliver the guilty,
rest: and he will escape because of the cleanness of your hands.”

firstLine: Job’s Eighth Speech: A Response to Eliphaz
rest: Then Job answered and said,

firstLine: “Even today my complaint is bitter;
rest: my hand is heavy in addition to my groaning.

firstLine: O that I knew and that I might find him;
rest: O that I might come to his dwelling.

firstLine: I would lay my case before him,
rest: and I would fill my mouth with arguments.

firstLine: I want to know the words with which he would answer me,
rest: and I want to understand what he would say to me.

firstLine: There an upright person could reason with him,
rest: and I would be acquitted forever by my judge.

firstLine: “When I go forward, he is not there,
rest: or backward, I cannot see him.

firstLine: When he works on the left, I cannot perceive him;
rest: he turns to the right, but I cannot see him.

firstLine: But he knows the way that I take;
rest: he tests me—I shall come out like gold.

firstLine: My foot has held on to his steps;
rest: I have kept his way, and I have not turned aside.

firstLine: From the commandment of his lips, indeed I have not departed;
rest: I have treasured the words of his mouth more than my daily food.

firstLine: “But he is alone, and who can dissuade him?
rest: And whatever he desires, indeed, he does it.

firstLine: For he will carry out what he appoints for me,
rest: and many things like these are with him.

firstLine: Therefore, I am horrified because of his presence;
rest: when I consider, I tremble because of him.

firstLine: Indeed, God has made my heart faint,
rest: and Shaddai has terrified me.

firstLine: Indeed, I have not been silenced because of darkness,
rest: and because of me he conceals thick darkness.

firstLine: Job’s Eighth Speech, Continued
rest:
“Why are not times kept by Shaddai,
and why do not those who know him see his days?

firstLine: They remove border stones;
rest: they seize flocks, and they pasture them.

firstLine: They drive away the donkey of orphans;
rest: they take the widow’s ox as a pledge.

firstLine: They thrust the poor off the road;
rest: the needy of the earth hide themselves together.

firstLine: “Look, like wild donkeys in the desert
rest:
they go out to their labor as searchers for the prey;
the wilderness is their food for the young.

firstLine: They reap their fodder in the field,
rest: and they glean in the vineyard of the wicked.

firstLine: They spend the night naked, without clothing,
rest: and they have no garment in the cold.

firstLine: They are wet from the rainstorm of the mountains,
rest: and they cling to the rock without refuge.

firstLine: “They snatch the orphan from the breast,
rest: and they take a pledge against the needy.

firstLine: They go about naked, without clothing,
rest: and hungry, they carry the sheaves.

firstLine: Between their terraces they press out oil;
rest: they tread the presses, but they are thirsty.

firstLine: From the city people groan,
rest:
and the throat of the wounded cries for help;
yet God does not regard it as unseemly.

firstLine: “Those are among the ones rebelling against the light;
rest:
they do not recognize his ways,
and they do not stay in his paths.

firstLine: At dusk the murderer rises;
rest:
he kills the needy and the poor,
and in the night he is like a thief.

firstLine: And the eye of the adulterer waits for dusk,
rest:
saying, ‘No eye will see me,’
and he places a covering on his face.

firstLine: He digs through houses in the darkness;
rest:
by day they shut themselves in—
they do not know the light

firstLine: because morning likewise is to them deep darkness;
rest: indeed, they know about the terrors of deep darkness.

firstLine: “He himself is swift on the water’s surface;
rest:
their portion is cursed in the land.
No one turns toward the path of their vineyards.

firstLine: Drought and heat snatch away the snow waters,
rest: like Sheol snatches away those who have sinned.

firstLine: He feeds on the barren, who does not have a child,
rest: and does no good to the widow.

firstLine: Yet he carries off the tyrants by his strength;
rest: if he rises up, then he cannot be certain of life.

firstLine: He gives security to him, and he is supported,
rest: but his eyes are upon their ways.

firstLine: “And if it is not so, then who can prove me a liar
rest: and reduce my word to nothing?”

firstLine: Bildad’s Third Speech
rest: Then Bildad the Shuhite answered and said,

firstLine: “Domination and dread are with him
rest: who makes peace in his high heavens.

firstLine: “Indeed, how can a human being be righteous before God?
rest: And how will he who is born of a woman be pure?

firstLine: Look, even the moon is not bright,
rest: and the stars are not pure in his sight.

firstLine: How much less for a human being who is a maggot,
rest: and a human who is a worm?”

firstLine: Job’s Ninth Speech: A Response to Bildad
rest: Then Job answered and said,

firstLine: “How you have helped one who has no power!
rest: How you have assisted the arm that has no strength!

firstLine: With whose help have you uttered words,
rest: and whose breath has come forth from you?

firstLine: “The spirits of the dead tremble
rest: below the waters and their inhabitants.

firstLine: Sheol is naked before him,
rest: and there is no covering for Abaddon.

firstLine: He stretches out the north over emptiness;
rest: he hangs the earth over nothing.

firstLine: He ties up the water in its clouds,
rest: and the cloud is not torn open beneath it.

firstLine: He covers the face of the full moon;
rest: he spreads his cloud over it.

firstLine: He has described a circle on the face of the water
rest: between light and darkness.

firstLine: “The pillars of heaven tremble,
rest: and they are astounded at his rebuke.

firstLine: By his power he stilled the sea,
rest: and by his understanding he struck down Rahab.

firstLine: By his breath the heavens were made clear;
rest: his hand pierced the fleeing snake.

firstLine: Look, these are the outer fringes of his ways,
rest:
and how faint is the word that we hear of him!
But who can understand the thunder of his power?”

firstLine: Job Continues His Final Speech
rest: Then Job again took up his discourse and said,

firstLine: “As God lives, he has removed my justice,
rest: and Shaddai has made my inner self bitter.

firstLine: For as long as my breath is in me,
rest: and the spirit of God is in my nose,

firstLine: my lips surely will not speak falseness,
rest: and my tongue surely will not utter deceit.

firstLine: Far be it from me that I would say that you are right;
rest: until I pass away, I will not put away from me my blamelessness.

firstLine: I hold fast to my righteousness, and I will not let it go;
rest: my heart will not blame any of my days.

firstLine: “Let my enemy be like the wicked
rest: and my opponent like the unrighteous,

firstLine: for what is the hope of the godless when he cuts them off,
rest: when God takes away his life?

firstLine: Will God hear his cry of distress
rest: when distress comes upon him?

firstLine: “I will teach you about God’s hand;
rest: I will not conceal that which is with Shaddai.

firstLine: Look, you all have seen,
rest: and why in the world have you become altogether vain?

firstLine: “This is the portion of the wicked human being with God,
rest: and they receive from Shaddai the inheritance of the ruthless.

firstLine: If their children multiply, it is for the sword,
rest: and his offspring do not have enough to eat.

firstLine: Their survivors are buried through the plague,
rest: and their widows do not weep.

firstLine: If he heaps up silver like the dust
rest: and fashions clothing like the clay,

firstLine: he makes it ready, and the righteous will wear it,
rest: and the innocent will divide the silver.

firstLine: “He builds his house like the moth,
rest: and like a booth that a watchman has made.

firstLine: He goes to bed with wealth, but he will do so no more;
rest: he opens his eyes, and it is gone.

firstLine: Terrors overtake him like the water;
rest: a storm wind carries him off in the night.

firstLine: The east wind lifts him up, and he is gone,
rest: and it sweeps him away from his place.

firstLine: And it hurls at him, and it has no compassion;
rest: he will quickly flee from its power.

firstLine: It claps its hands over him,
rest: and it hisses at him from its place.

firstLine: Job’s Discourse on Wisdom
rest:
“Indeed, there is a mine for silver
and a place for gold to be refined.

firstLine: Iron is taken from dust,
rest: and he pours out copper from ore.

firstLine: He puts an end to darkness,
rest:
and he searches out the farthest limits
for the ore in gloom and deep shadow.

firstLine: He breaks open a mine shaft away from where people dwell;
rest:
those who are forgotten by travelers,
they dangle, they sway far away from human beings.

firstLine: As for the earth, from it comes food,
rest: but underneath it, it is turned up as by fire.

firstLine: Its stones are the place of sapphire,
rest: and the earthen dirt has gold.

firstLine: “It is a path a bird of prey does not know
rest: and the black kite’s eye has not seen.

firstLine: Proud wild animals have not trodden it;
rest: the lion in its prime has not prowled over it.

firstLine: He puts his hand on the hard rock;
rest: he overturns mountains by the roots.

firstLine: He cuts out tunnels in the rocks,
rest: and his eye sees every treasure.

firstLine: He dams up rivers from their sources,
rest: and he brings secret things to the light.

firstLine: “But from where will wisdom be found?
rest: And where in the world is the place of understanding?

firstLine: A human being does not know its proper value,
rest: and it is not found in the land of the living.

firstLine: The deep says, ‘It is not in me,’
rest: and the sea says, ‘It is not with me.’

firstLine: “Refined gold cannot be gotten in its place,
rest: and silver cannot be weighed out as its price.

firstLine: It cannot be bought for the gold of Ophir,
rest: for precious onyx or sapphire.

firstLine: Gold and glass cannot be compared with it,
rest: and its substitution cannot be an ornament of refined gold.

firstLine: Black corals and crystal will not be mentioned,
rest: and wisdom’s price is more than red corals.

firstLine: The topaz of Cush cannot be compared with it;
rest: it cannot be bought for pure gold.

firstLine: It is hidden from the eyes of all living,
rest: and it is concealed from the birds of the heaven.

firstLine: Abaddon and Death say,
rest: ‘We heard its rumor with our ears.’

firstLine: “God understands its way,
rest: and he knows its place,

firstLine: for he himself looks to the end of the earth;
rest: he sees under all the heaven.

firstLine: When he gave weight to the wind
rest: and he apportioned the waters by measure,

firstLine: when he made a rule for the rain
rest: and a way for the thunder’s lightning bolt,

firstLine: then he saw it and talked about it;
rest: he established it, and moreover, he explored it.

firstLine: And to the human beings he said,
rest:
‘Look, the fear of the Lord is wisdom,
and to depart from evil is understanding.’”

firstLine: Job’s Final Defense
rest: Then Job again took up his discourse and said,

firstLine: “O that I were as in the months before,
rest: as in the days when God watched over me,

firstLine: when his shining lamp was over my head—
rest: by his light I walked through darkness—

firstLine: as when I was in the days of my prime,
rest: when God’s confiding was over my house,

firstLine: when Shaddaiwas still with me,
rest: my children were all around me,

firstLine: when my paths were washed in sour milk,
rest: and the rock poured out streams of oil for me.

firstLine: “At my going out the gate to the city,
rest: I secured my seat in the square.

firstLine: Young men saw me and stepped aside,
rest: and the aged rose up and stood.

firstLine: Officials refrained from talking,
rest: and they laid their hand on their mouth.

firstLine: The voices of nobles were hushed,
rest: and their tongue stuck to their palate.

firstLine: “When the ear heard and commended me,
rest: and the eye saw and testified in support of me

firstLine: because I saved the needy who cried for help,
rest: and I saved the orphan for whom there was no helper.

firstLine: The blessing of the wretched came upon me,
rest: and I caused the widow’s heart to sing for joy.

firstLine: I put on righteousness, and it clothed me;
rest: my justice was like a robe and a headband.

firstLine: “I was eyes to the blind,
rest: and I was feet to the lame.

firstLine: I was a father to the poor,
rest: and I investigated the stranger’s legal dispute.

firstLine: And I broke the evil one’s jaw bones,
rest: and I made his prey drop from his teeth.

firstLine: “And I thought, ‘I will pass away in my nest,
rest: and like the phoenix I shall multiply my days.

firstLine: My roots were open to water,
rest: and dew spent the night on my branches;

firstLine: My glory was new with me,
rest: and I was revitalized regularly.’

firstLine: “They listened to me and waited,
rest: and they kept silent for my counsel.

firstLine: After my word, they did not speak again,
rest: and my word dropped down like dew upon them.

firstLine: And they waited for me as for the rain,
rest: and they opened their mouth wide as for the spring rain.

firstLine: I smiled for them when they had no confidence in anything,
rest: and they did not extinguish the light of my face.

firstLine: I chose their way, and I sat as head,
rest:
and I dwelled like a king among the troops,
like one who comforts mourners.

firstLine: Job’s Final Defense Continued
rest:
“But now those younger than I, as far as days, laugh at me,
whose fathers I rejected for setting with the dogs of my sheep and goats.

firstLine: Through want and through barren hunger
rest: they are gnawing in the dry region in the darkness of desolation and waste.

firstLine: They are picking salt herbs, the leaves of bushes,
rest: and the roots of broom trees to warm themselves.

firstLine: They were driven out from fellow people;
rest: they shout at them as at a thief,

firstLine: so that they dwell
rest: in holes of the ground and in the rocks.

firstLine: They bray among the bushes;
rest: they are gathered under the nettles.

firstLine: A senseless crowd, yes, a disreputable brood,
rest: they were cast out from the land.

firstLine: “But now I am their mocking song,
rest: and I have become a byword for them.

firstLine: They abhor me; they keep aloof from me,
rest: and they do not withhold spit from my face

firstLine: because he has loosened his bowstring and humbled me,
rest: and they have thrown off restraint in my presence.

firstLine: On the right hand the brood rises up;
rest:
they put me to flight,
and they build up their siege ramps against me.

firstLine: They destroy my path;
rest:
they promote my destruction;
they have no helper.

firstLine: As through a wide breach they come;
rest: amid a crash they rush on.

firstLine: Terrors are turned upon me;
rest:
my honor is pursued as by the wind,
and my hope of deliverance passed by like a cloud.

firstLine: “And now my life is poured out onto me;
rest: days of misery have taken hold of me.

firstLine: At night I am in great pain;
rest: my pains do not take a rest.

firstLine: He seizes my clothing with great power;
rest: he grasps me by my tunic’s collar.

firstLine: He has cast me into the dirt,
rest: and I have become like dust and ashes.

firstLine: I cry to you for help, but you do not answer me;
rest: I stand, and you merely look at me.

firstLine: You have turned cruel to me;
rest: you persecute me with your hand’s might.

firstLine: You lift me up to the wind—you make me ride it,
rest: and you toss me about in the storm.

firstLine: Indeed, I know that you will bring me to death
rest: and to the house of assembly for all the living.

firstLine: “Surely someone must not send a hand against the needy
rest: when, in his misfortune, there is a cry of help for them.

firstLine: Have I not wept for the unfortunate,
rest: and grieved myself over the poor?

firstLine: Indeed, I hoped for good, but evil came,
rest: and I waited for light, but darkness came.

firstLine: My bowels are in turmoil, and they are not still;
rest: days of misery come to confront me.

firstLine: I go about in mourning garb, but not in sunlight;
rest: I stand up in the assembly, and I cry for help.

firstLine: I am a companion for the jackals
rest: and a companion for ostriches.

firstLine: My skin turns black on me,
rest: and my bones burn with heat.

firstLine: So my lyre came to be used for mourning,
rest: and my flute for the voice of those who weep.

firstLine: Job’s Final Defense Continued
rest:
“I made a covenant with my eyes,
so how could I look closely upon a virgin?

firstLine: And what is the portion of God from above
rest: or the heritage of Shaddai from on high?

firstLine: Is not disaster for the evil one
rest: and ruin for the workers of mischief?

firstLine: Does he not see my ways
rest: and count all my steps?

firstLine: “If I have walked with falseness,
rest: and my foot has hastened to deceit,

firstLine: let him weigh me in the balance of justice,
rest: and let God know my blamelessness.

firstLine: If my steps have turned aside from the way,
rest:
and my heart has walked after my eyes,
and my hand has clung to a spot,

firstLine: let me sow, and let another eat,
rest: and let my crops be rooted out.

firstLine: “If my heart has been enticed by a woman,
rest: and at my neighbor’s doorway I have lain in wait,

firstLine: let my wife grind for another,
rest: and let other men kneel over her,

firstLine: for that is a shameful act,
rest: and that is a criminal offense.

firstLine: Indeed, that is a fire that will consume up to Abaddon,
rest: and it would uproot all my crop.

firstLine: “If I have rejected my male or female slave’s case
rest: when their complaint was against me,

firstLine: “If I have withheld the desire of the poor from them,
rest: or I have caused the widow’s eyes to fail,

firstLine: or I have eaten my morsel alone,
rest: and the orphan has not eaten from it

firstLine: (for from my childhood he grew up with me like a father,
rest: and from my mother’s womb I guided her),

firstLine: if I have seen the one who perishes because of no clothing
rest: or that there is no covering for the poor,

firstLine: if his loins have not blessed me,
rest: or by means of my sheep’s fleece he has warmed himself,

firstLine: if I have raised my hand against an orphan
rest: because I saw my supporters at the gate,

firstLine: then let my shoulder blade fall from my shoulder,
rest: and let my arm be broken from its socket.

firstLine: Indeed, the disaster from God was a dread for me,
rest: and I was powerless because of his majesty.

firstLine: “If I have made gold my trust,
rest: or I have called fine gold my security,

firstLine: if I have rejoiced because my wealth was great
rest: or because my hand found a fortune,

firstLine: if I looked at the sun when it shone
rest: or at the moon moving in splendor,
