firstLine: Like snow in the summer and like rain at the harvest,
rest: so honor is not fitting for a fool.

firstLine: Like the sparrow is to fluttering and like the swallow is to flying,
rest: so an undeserved curse does not go forth.

firstLine: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey,
rest: and a rod for the back of fools.

firstLine: Do not answer a fool according to his folly
rest: lest you become like him—even you.

firstLine: Answer a fool according to his folly,
rest: or else he will be wise in his own eyes.

firstLine: Like cutting off feet or drinking violence,
rest: so is he who sends messages in the hand of a fool.

firstLine: Like legs that hang limp from a lame person,
rest: so is a proverb in the mouth of fools.

firstLine: Like binding a stone in a sling,
rest: so is giving honor to a fool.

firstLine: Like a thorn that goes up in the hand of a drunkard,
rest: so is a proverb in the mouth of fools.

firstLine: Like an archer who wounds everyone,
rest: so is he who hires a fool or he who hires passersby.

firstLine: Like a dog returning to his vomit
rest: is a fool reverting to his folly.

firstLine: The door turns on its hinge,
rest: and a lazy person on his bed.

firstLine: A lazy person buries his hands in the dish;
rest: he is too tired to return it to his mouth.

firstLine: A lazy person is wiser in his eyes
rest: than seven who answer discreetly.

firstLine: Grabbing onto the ears of a dog
rest: passing by is one who meddles in a quarrel that is not his own.

firstLine: Like a maniac who shoots
rest: firebrands, arrows, and death,

firstLine: so is a man who deceives his neighbor,
rest: but says “Am I not joking?”

firstLine: For lack of wood, a fire goes out,
rest: and where there is no whisperer, quarreling will cease.

firstLine: As charcoal is to hot embers and wood is to fire,
rest: so a man of quarrels is to kindling strife.

firstLine: The words of a whisperer are like delicious morsels,
rest: and they go down to the inner parts of the body.

firstLine: Like impure silver which overlays an earthen vessel,
rest: so are smooth lips and an evil heart.

firstLine: On his lips, an enemy will pretend,
rest: but inside he will harbor deceit.

firstLine: When he makes his voice gracious, do not believe him,
rest: for seven abominations are in his heart.

firstLine: Though hatred is covered with guile,
rest: its evil will be exposed in the assembly.

firstLine: He who digs a pit, in it he will fall,
rest: and he who rolls a stone, on him it will come back.

firstLine: A tongue of deceit hates its victim,
rest: and a flattering mouth makes ruin.

firstLine: Do not boast about tomorrow,
rest: for you do not know what the day will bring.

firstLine: May another praise you and not your own mouth,
rest: a stranger and not your own lips.

firstLine: Heavy is a stone and weighty is sand,
rest: but the provocation of a fool is heavier than both of them.

firstLine: Cruel is wrath and overwhelming is anger,
rest: but who will stand before jealousy?

firstLine: Better a rebuke that is open
rest: than a love that is hidden.

firstLine: The wounds of a friend mean well,
rest: but the kisses of an enemy are profane.

firstLine: An appetite that is sated spurns honey,
rest: but to an appetite that is ravenous, all bitterness is sweet.

firstLine: Like a bird that strays from its nest,
rest: so is a man who strays from his place.

firstLine: Perfume and incense will gladden a heart,
rest: and the pleasantness of one’s friend is personal advice.

firstLine: As for your friend and a friend of your father, do not forsake them,
rest:
and the house of your brother, do not enter on the day of your calamity.
Better is a close neighbor than a distant brother.

firstLine: Be wise, my child, and make my heart glad,
rest: and I will answer him who reproaches me with a word.

firstLine: When the clever sees danger, he hides;
rest: the simple go on and suffer.

firstLine: Take his garment, for he gives surety to a stranger,
rest: and to an adulteress—so take his pledge.

firstLine: He who blesses his neighbor with a loud voice
rest:
early in the morning,
a curse will be reckoned to him.

firstLine: Dripping constantly on a day of heavy rain
rest: and a woman of contention are alike.

firstLine: In restraining her, he restrains wind,
rest: and his right hand will grasp oil.

firstLine: As iron sharpens iron,
rest: so one man sharpens another.

firstLine: He who tends a fig tree will eat its fruit,
rest: and he who guards his master will be honored.

firstLine: As the waters reflect face to face,
rest: so the heart of a person reflects the person.

firstLine: Sheol and Abaddon will not be satisfied,
rest: and the eyes of a person will not be satisfied either.

firstLine: A crucible is for the silver, and a furnace for the gold,
rest: but a man is tested by the mouth of him who praises him.

firstLine: If you crush a fool in the mortar with the pestle along with the crushed grain,
rest: it will not drive folly from upon him.

firstLine: You will surely know the condition of your flock;
rest: your heart attends to the herds.

firstLine: For riches are not forever,
rest: nor a crown for generation after generation.

firstLine: When the grass is gone, then green growth will appear,
rest: and the herbs of the mountains will be gathered.

firstLine: Lambs will be your clothing,
rest: and goats the price of the field.

firstLine: And there will be enough goats’ milk for your food,
rest: for the food of your household and the nourishment of your maidservants.

firstLine: The wicked flee, but no one pursues,
rest: but the righteous is bold like a lion.

firstLine: By the rebellion of a land, her rulers increase,
rest: but by a person of intelligence who knows justice, it will last.

firstLine: A man who is poor and oppresses the impoverished
rest: is a beating rain that leaves no food.

firstLine: Those who forsake instruction will praise the wicked,
rest: but they who guard instruction will struggle against them.

firstLine: Men of evil do not understand justice,
rest: but seekers of Yahweh understand completely.

firstLine: Better to be poor and walking in one’s integrity
rest: than to be crooked of ways when one is rich.

firstLine: He who keeps instruction is a child of understanding,
rest: but the companion of gluttons will shame his father.

firstLine: He who augments his wealth with interest and with usury
rest: gathers it for him who is kind to the poor.

firstLine: He who turns his ear from listening to instruction,
rest: even his prayer is an abomination.

firstLine: He who misleads the upright onto the way of evil,
rest:
into his pits he will fall.
But as for the blameless, they will inherit good.

firstLine: A man of wealth is wise in his own eyes,
rest: but the intelligent poor sees through him.

firstLine: When the righteous triumphs, great is the glory,
rest: but with the rising of the wicked, a person will be hidden.

firstLine: He who conceals his transgression will not prosper,
rest: but he who confesses and forsakes will obtain mercy.

firstLine: Happy is the person who fears continuously,
rest: but he who is stubborn of heart, will fall into calamity.

firstLine: Like a roaring lion and a charging bear
rest: is a wicked ruler over a poor people.

firstLine: A ruler who lacks understanding is a cruel oppressor,
rest: but those who hate unjust gain will have long days.

firstLine: A person who is burdened with the blood of another,
rest:
until death he will flee;
do not take hold of him.

firstLine: He who walks in integrity will be safe,
rest: but he who takes crooked paths will fall in one.

firstLine: He who tills his ground will have plenty bread,
rest: but he who follows fantasies will have plenty of poverty.

firstLine: A man of faithfulness has abundant blessings,
rest: but he who hurries to become rich will not go unpunished.

firstLine: Showing partiality is not good,
rest: and over a morsel of bread, a strong man will do wrong.

firstLine: He who hurries for wealth is a man with an evil eye,
rest: but he does not know that poverty will come upon him.

firstLine: He who rebukes a person will afterward find more favor
rest: than he who flatters with the tongue.

firstLine: He who robs his father and his mother and says, “There is no crime,”
rest: is partner to a man who corrupts.

firstLine: The greedy person will stir up strife,
rest: but he who trusts in Yahweh will be enriched.

firstLine: He who trusts in his own heart is a fool,
rest: but he who walks in wisdom will be saved.

firstLine: For he who gives to the poor, there is no lacking,
rest: but for he who turns his eyes, there are many curses.

firstLine: With the rising of the wicked, humankind will be hidden,
rest: and with their perishing, the righteous will multiply.

firstLine: A man who is reproved, being stubborn of neck—
rest: suddenly he will be broken, and there will not be healing.

firstLine: When the righteous are numerous, the people will rejoice,
rest: but when the wicked are ruling, people will groan.

firstLine: A man who loves wisdom will make his parents glad,
rest: but the friend of prostitutes will squander his wealth.

firstLine: By justice a king gives stability to a land,
rest: but a man of bribes will ruin it.

firstLine: A strong man who flatters his neighbor
rest: is spreading a net for his feet.

firstLine: In transgression, an evil man is a snare,
rest: but the righteous will sing and rejoice.

firstLine: The righteous knows the case of the poor,
rest: but the wicked does not understand knowledge.

firstLine: Men of scoffing set a city aflame,
rest: but the wise turn away wrath.

firstLine: If a wise man goes to court with a foolish man,
rest: then there is rankling and ridicule, but there is no relief.

firstLine: Men of blood hate the blameless,
rest: and they seek the life of the upright.

firstLine: A fool gives all his breath,
rest: but the wise holds back in quiet.

firstLine: A ruler listening to a word of falsehood,
rest: all his officials are wicked.

firstLine: The poor and a man of oppression have this in common:
rest: Yahweh gives light to the eyes of them both.

firstLine: A king who judges with truthfulness to the poor,
rest: his throne will be established forever.

firstLine: As for a rod and reproof, they will give wisdom,
rest: but a neglected child is disgraced by his mother.

firstLine: With the increase of the wicked, transgression will increase,
rest: but the righteous will look on his downfall.

firstLine: Discipline your children, and they will give you rest,
rest: and they will give delight to your soul.

firstLine: When there is no prophecy, the people cast off restraint,
rest: but as for he who guards instruction, happiness is his.

firstLine: By words, a servant is not disciplined,
rest: for he will understand, but there is no giving heed.

firstLine: You see a man who is hasty in his words:
rest: there is more hope for a fool than him.

firstLine: He who pampers his servant from childhood,
rest: arrogance will be his end.

firstLine: A man of anger will stir strife,
rest: and the owner of anger, much transgression.

firstLine: The pride of a person will bring him humiliation,
rest: and the lowly of spirit will obtain honor.

firstLine: Being a partner with a thief is hating one’s life;
rest: a curse he will hear, but not disclose.

firstLine: The fear of a person will lay a snare,
rest: but he who trusts in Yahweh will be secure.

firstLine: Many are those who seek the favor of a ruler,
rest: but from Yahweh one obtains justice.

firstLine: A man of injustice is an abomination to the righteous,
rest: but the upright is an abomination to the wicked.

firstLine: The Oracle of Agur
rest:
The words of Agur, son of Yakeh, the oracle.
Thus says the man to Ithiel, to Ithiel, and Ucal:

firstLine: Certainly I am more stupid than a man,
rest: and the understanding of humankind is not for me.

firstLine: And I have not learned wisdom,
rest: nor will I know knowledge of the Holy One.

firstLine: Every word of God is flawless;
rest: he is a shield for him who takes refuge in him.

firstLine: Do not add to his words
rest: lest he rebuke you and you be found a liar.

firstLine: Two things I ask from you;
rest: do not deny me before I die:

firstLine: Keep falsehood and a lying word far from me;
rest:
do not give me poverty or wealth;
provide me with food only for my need.

firstLine: Or else I will be satisfied and will deny him
rest:
and say “Who is Yahweh?”
Or I will be poor and will steal
and profane the name of my God.

firstLine: Do not slander a servant to his master,
rest: or else he will curse you and you will be guilty.

firstLine: There is a generation that will curse its father,
rest: and its mother it will not bless.

firstLine: There is a generation that is pure in its own eyes,
rest: but from its filthiness it will not be cleansed.

firstLine: There is a generation whose teeth are swords,
rest:
and its jawbones, knives,
in order to devour the poor from the earth
and the needy from humankind.

firstLine: For the leech, there are two daughters;
Sheol and barrenness of womb,
rest:
the land is not satisfied with water,
and fire does not say “enough!”

firstLine: The eye that mocks a father
rest:
and scorns the obedience of a mother—
the ravens of the valley will peck it out,
and the offspring of vultures will eat it.

firstLine: Three of these are too wonderful for me,
rest: and four, I do not understand them:

firstLine: the way of the eagle in the sky,
rest:
the way of a snake on a rock,
the way of a ship in the heart of the sea,
and the way of a man with a young woman.

firstLine: This is the way of a woman committing adultery:
rest:
she eats and wipes her mouth,
and says “I have not done wrong.”

firstLine: Under three things the earth trembles,
rest: and under four, it is not able to bear up:

firstLine: under a slave when he becomes king,
rest: and a fool when he is satisfied with food;

firstLine: under an unloved woman when she gets married,
rest: and a maid when she succeeds her mistress.

firstLine: There are four small things on the earth,
rest: and they are exceedingly wise:

firstLine: The ants are a people who are not strong,
rest: yet they prepare their food in the summer;

firstLine: the badgers are a people who are not mighty,
rest: yet they set their house on the rock;

firstLine: there is no king for the locust,
rest: yet it marches in rank;

firstLine: a lizard you can seize with hands,
rest: yet it is in palaces of kings.

firstLine: There are three things that are magnificent of stride,
rest: and four that are magnificent when moving:

firstLine: a mighty lion among the beasts,
rest: but he will not turn back from any face;

firstLine: a strutting rooster or he-goat,
rest: and a king whose army is with him.

firstLine: If you have been foolish by exalting yourself,
rest: and if you have devised evil, put your hand to your mouth.

firstLine: For pressing milk produces curd,
rest:
and pressing the nose produces blood,
so pressing anger produces strife.

firstLine: The Oracle of King Lemuel
rest:
The words of Lemuel, the king—an oracle
that his mother taught him:

firstLine: Do not give your strength to the women,
rest: and your ways to destroy kings.

firstLine: It is not for the kings, O Lemuel;
rest:
drinking wine is not for the kings,
nor is strong drink for rulers.

firstLine: Or else he will drink and forget what has been decreed,
rest: and he will pervert the rights of all the afflicted.

firstLine: Give strong drink to him who is perishing,
rest: and wine to those in bitter distress.

firstLine: He will drink and forget his poverty,
rest: and his misery he will not remember any more.

firstLine: Open your mouth for the mute,
rest: for the rights of all the needy.

firstLine: Open your mouth, judge righteousness,
rest: and defend the poor and needy.

firstLine: An Excellent Woman
rest:
A woman of excellence, who will find?
For her worth is far more than precious jewels.

firstLine: The heart of her husband trusts in her,
rest: and gain he will not lack.

firstLine: She does him good, but not harm
rest: all the days of her life.

firstLine: She seeks wool and flax,
rest: and she works with the diligence of her hands.

firstLine: She is like the ships of a merchant;
rest: from far off she brings her food;

firstLine: And she arises while it is still night,
rest:
and gives food to her household,
and tasks to her servant girls.

firstLine: She considers a field and buys it,
rest: from the fruit of her hand she plants a vineyard.

firstLine: She girds her waist in strength,
rest: and makes her arms strong.

firstLine: She perceives that her merchandise is good;
rest: her lamp does not go out in the night.

firstLine: Her hands she puts onto the distaff,
rest: and her palms hold a spindle.

firstLine: Her palm she opens to the poor,
rest: and her hand she reaches out to the needy.

firstLine: She does not fear for her house when it snows,
rest: for her entire household is clothed in crimson.

firstLine: She makes for herself coverings;
rest: her clothing is fine linen and purple.

firstLine: Her husband is known at the gates,
rest: in his seat among the elders of the land.

firstLine: Linen garments she makes and sells,
rest: and she supplies sashes for the merchants.

firstLine: Strength and dignity are her clothing,
rest: and she laughs at the future.

firstLine: She opens her mouth with wisdom,
rest: and instruction of kindness is upon her tongue.

firstLine: She looks after the ways of her household,
rest: and the bread of idleness she will not eat.

firstLine: Her children rise and consider her happy,
rest: her husband also, and he praises her;

firstLine: “Many daughters have done excellence,
rest: but you surpass all of them.”

firstLine: Charm is deceit and beauty is vain;
rest: but a woman who fears Yahweh shall be praised.

firstLine: Give to her from the fruit of her hand,
rest: and may they praise her works in the city gates.

firstLine: Prologue
rest: The words of the Teacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.

firstLine: Motto Introduced
rest:
“Vanity of vanities!” says the Teacher,
“Vanity of vanities! All is vanity!”

firstLine: All Toil is Profitless and Repetitious
rest:
What does a person gain in all his toil
with which he toils under the sun?

firstLine: A generation goes, and a generation comes,
rest: but the earth stands forever.

firstLine: The sun rises, and the sun goes down;
rest: to its place it hurries, and there it rises again.

firstLine: The wind goes to the south and goes around to the north;
rest: around and around it goes, and on its circuit the wind returns.

firstLine: All the streams flow to the sea,
All things toil continuously;
rest:
no one can ever finish describing this.
The eye is never satisfied with seeing,
and the ear is never filled with hearing.

firstLine: What has been—it is what will be;
rest:
what has been done—it is what will be done;
there is nothing new under the sun.

firstLine: There is neither remembrance of former generations,
rest: nor will there be remembrance of future generations.

firstLine: Qohelet Introduces His Quest
rest: I, the Teacher, was king over Israel in Jerusalem.

firstLine: What is twisted cannot be straightened,
rest: and what is lacking cannot be counted.

firstLine: For in much wisdom is much frustration,
rest: and whoever increases knowledge increases sorrow.

firstLine: Qohelet’s Investigation of Self-Indulgence
rest: I said to myself, “Come! I will test pleasure to see whether it is worthwhile.” But look, “This also is vanity!”

firstLine: Qohelet’s Investigation of Personal Accomplishment
rest: I accomplished great things. I built for myself houses; I planted for myself vineyards.

firstLine: The Living Must Abandon the Work of their Hands to Others at Death
rest: Next, I considered wisdom, as well as delusion and folly. What can anyone do who will come after the king that has not already been done?

firstLine: It is Best to Simply Enjoy the Passing Pleasures of Life as Reward for Pleasing God
rest: There is nothing better for a person than to eat and drink and find delight in his toil. For I also realized that this is from the hand of God!

firstLine: God Has Ordained the Ebb and Flow of Human Activities
rest: For everything there is an appointed time, a time for every matter under heaven:

firstLine: a time to bear and a time to die;
rest: a time to plant and a time to root up what is planted;

firstLine: a time to kill and a time to heal;
rest: a time to break down and a time to build up;

firstLine: a time to weep and a time to laugh;
rest: a time to mourn and a time to dance;

firstLine: a time to throw away stones and a time to gather stones;
rest: a time to embrace and a time to refrain from embracing;

firstLine: a time to seek and a time to lose;
rest: a time to keep and a time to throw away;

firstLine: a time to tear and a time to sew;
rest: a time to be silent and a time to speak;

firstLine: a time to love and a time to hate;
rest: a time for war and a time for peace.

firstLine: No One Understands God’s Mysterious Plan
rest: I have seen the busyness God gives to humans to preoccupy them.

firstLine: I know everything God does endures forever;
rest:
nothing can be added to it, and nothing can be taken from it,
for God so acts that humans might stand in awe before him.

firstLine: What is—it already was,
rest:
and what will be—it already is,
for God will do what he has done.

firstLine: God’s Mysterious Plan Allows Injustice to Exist in the World
rest: I saw something else under the sun: instead of justice there was evil; instead of righteousness there was wickedness.

firstLine: The Existence of Oppression in the World Makes Human Existence Miserable
rest:
I looked again, and I saw all the oppression that occurs under the sun.
I saw the tears of the oppressed—
no one comforts them!
Those who oppress them are powerful—
no one can comfort them!

firstLine: So I deemed the dead who have already died
rest: more fortunate than the living who are still alive.

firstLine: But better off than both of them is the one who has not yet been born
rest: and has not seen the evil deeds that are done under the sun.

firstLine: People Need Balance in Their Approach to Labor
rest: I also realized that all of the toil and all of the skillful work that is done—it is envy between one man and another. This also is vanity and chasing wind!

firstLine: The fool refuses to work with his hands,
rest: so he has nothing to eat except his own skin!

firstLine: Better is one handful with peace
rest: than two fists full with toil and chasing wind.

firstLine: Wealth without Someone with Which to Enjoy It is Futile
rest: I turned again and saw another vanity under the sun.

firstLine: Friends and Family Can Help One Another in Life
rest: Two are better than the one, for they enjoy a better reward for their toil.

firstLine: One Must Be Willing to Listen to Counsel
rest: A poor but wise youth is better than an old but foolish king who no longer knows how to receive advice.

firstLine: Listen to God Rather Than Uttering Rash Vows
Do not be rash with your mouth,
For a dream comes with many cares,
rest: and the voice of a fool with many words.

firstLine: When you make a vow to God,
rest:
do not delay in fulfilling it,
for he takes no pleasure in fools.
Fulfill what you vow!

firstLine: It is better that you not vow
rest: than that you vow and not fulfill it.

firstLine: Do not let your mouth lead your flesh into sin,
rest:
and do not tell the messenger that it was a mistake.
Why anger God at your words,
so that he destroys the work of your hands?

firstLine: Powerful Bureaucrats Exploit the Helpless Poor
rest:
Do not be surprised if you see the poor being oppressed with violence
or do not see justice and righteousness in the province.
For one official is watched by a higher official,
and there are even higher officials over them!

firstLine: The produce of the land is exploited by everyone;
rest: even the king profits from the field of the poor!

firstLine: There is Never Enough Money to Satisfy
rest:
Whoever loves money is not satisfied with money,
and whoever loves wealth is not satisfied with profit.
This also is vanity!

firstLine: When prosperity increases,
rest:
those who consume it increase.
So its owner gains nothing,
except to see his wealth before it is spent.

firstLine: The sleep of the laborer is pleasant, whether he eats little or much,
rest: but the wealth of the rich man does not allow him to rest.

firstLine: Hoarding Wealth Can Backfire
rest: There is a grievous evil which I have seen under the sun: wealth hoarded by its owner to his harm.

firstLine: If You Have Wealth, Enjoy It as God Enables
rest: Look! I have discovered what is good and fitting: to eat and to drink and to enjoy all the fruit of the toil with which one toils under the sun during the number of the days of his life that God gives to him—for this is his lot.

firstLine: Those Who Have Wealth but Do Not Enjoy It Are Pitiful
rest: Here is another misfortune that I have seen under the sun, and it is prevalent among humankind.

firstLine: One Must Learn to Be Content with What One Has
rest:
All of a man’s toil is for his mouth—
yet his appetite is never satisfied.

firstLine: Better to be content with what your eyes see
rest:
than for your soul to constantly crave more.
This also is vanity and chasing wind!

firstLine: It is Futile for Humans to Complain about God’s Irresistible Will
rest:
Whatever is—it was already determined,
what will be—it has already been decided.
As for man, he cannot argue
against what is more powerful than him.

firstLine: Increasing words only multiplies futility,
rest: how does that profit anyone?

firstLine: The Future is Inscrutable to Humans
rest: For who knows what is good for a man in his life during the few days of his fleeting life, which are fleeting as a shadow? For who can tell anyone what will happen in the future under the sun?

firstLine: People Generally Do Not Know What is Best for Them
rest:
A good name is better than precious ointment,
and the day of death is better than the day of one’s birth.

firstLine: Better to go to the house of mourning
Sorrow is better than laughter,
rest: for by sadness of countenance the heart is made good.

firstLine: The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning,
rest: but the heart of fools is in the house of mirth.

firstLine: Better to listen to the rebuke of the wise
rest: than for a man to listen to the song of fools.

firstLine: Like the sound of thorns under a pot,
rest:
so also the laughter of fools.
This also is vanity!

firstLine: Wisdom—Although Vulnerable—is Beneficial
rest:
Surely oppression makes a fool of the wise,
and a bribe corrupts the heart.

firstLine: The end of a matter is better than its beginning;
rest: better to be slow to anger than hot-headed.

firstLine: Do not be quick in your spirit to anger,
rest: for anger lodges in the bosom of fools.

firstLine: Wisdom is good with an inheritance;
rest: it benefits the living.

firstLine: Humans Must Accept God’s Will and Make the Best of It
rest:
Consider the work of God.
For who is able to make straight what he made crooked?

firstLine: The Law of Retribution Does Not Always Work—but It Does Sometimes
rest:
I have seen all these things in my vain life:
Sometimes a righteous man perishes in spite of his righteousness,
and sometimes a wicked man lives a long life in spite of his evil.

firstLine: Do not be excessively righteous,
rest: and do not act excessively wise, lest you destroy yourself.

firstLine: Do not act excessively wicked,
rest: and do not be a fool, lest you die before your time.

firstLine: It is good to take hold of the one and also must not let go of the other;
rest: for whoever fears God will hold both of them secure.

firstLine: Wisdom is Valuable, but No One is Completely Righteous
rest:
Wisdom gives more strength to the wise
than ten rulers who are in the city.

firstLine: Surely there is no one righteous on the earth
rest: who continually does good and never sins.

firstLine: Do not pay attention to everything people say,
rest: lest you hear your own servant curse you.

firstLine: For your heart knows
rest: that you also have cursed others many times.

firstLine: Absolute Wisdom is Unattainable
rest: All this I have tested with wisdom. I said, “I will be wise!” but it was beyond my grasp.

firstLine: Wisdom is Valuable
rest:
Who is like the sage?
Who knows the interpretation of a thing?
A man’s wisdom makes his face shine,
and the hardness of his face is changed.

firstLine: Keep the command of the king
rest: because of your oath to God.

firstLine: Since the word of the king is supreme,
rest: no one can say to him, “What are you doing?”

firstLine: For there is a proper time and right procedure for every matter,
rest: even though the trouble of man weighs heavy upon him.

firstLine: No One Knows the Future
rest:
Surely no one knows what will be,
so who can tell anyone what will happen?

firstLine: Just as no one can control the wind to restrain the wind,
rest:
so also no one can control the day of his death.
Just as no one is discharged in time of war,
so wickedness will not deliver the wicked.

firstLine: The World Marred by Oppression and Injustice
rest: I saw all this as I applied my heart to all the deeds done under the sun: sometimes those in authority harm others.

firstLine: Although Evil is Not Punished Swiftly, God Does Eventually Punish Sinners
rest: Because sentence against an evil deed is not carried out quickly, the heart of humans fills up within them to do evil.

firstLine: Humans Should Enjoy the Life That God Gives to Them
rest: So I recommend enjoyment. For there is nothing better for man under the sun than to eat and to drink and to rejoice. This will accompany him in his toil the days of his life that God gives to him under the sun.

firstLine: No One Can Discover the Rhyme and Reason for Things
rest: I applied my mind to know wisdom and to understand the business that is done on earth—how neither day nor night one’s eyes see sleep.

firstLine: The Same Fate—Death—Awaits Everyone
rest: So all this I laid to my heart, and I concluded that the righteous and the wise, as well as their deeds, are in the hand of God. So no one knows anything that will come to them, whether it will be love or hatred.

firstLine: The same fate comes to everyone:
rest:
to the righteous and to the wicked,
to the good and to the wicked,
to the clean and to the unclean,
to those who sacrifice and to those who do not sacrifice.
As with the good man, so also to the sinner;
as with those who swear an oath, so also those who fear oaths.

firstLine: This is the injustice that is done under the sun:
Death Deprives Humans of Everything in Life
rest: Whoever is joined to all the living has hope. After all, even a live dog is better than a dead lion!

firstLine: Enjoy Life While It Lasts
rest: Go—eat your food with joy, and drink your wine with a merry heart! For God already has approved your deeds.

firstLine: The Injustice of Time and Chance
rest: I looked again and saw under the sun that the race does not belong to the swift, the battle does not belong to the mighty, food does not belong to the wise, wealth does not belong to the intelligent, and success does not belong to the skillful, for time and chance befalls all of them.

firstLine: Wisdom—Although Vulnerable—is Superior to Power
rest: I have also seen this example of wisdom under the sun, and it seemed great to me.

firstLine: Wisdom—Although Vulnerable—is Superior to Folly
rest:
The words of the wise are heard in peace
more than the shouting of a ruler is heard among the fools.

firstLine: Wisdom is better than weapons of war,
rest: but one sinner destroys much good.

firstLine: The heart of the wise inclines to his right,
rest: but the heart of the fool inclines to his left.

firstLine: Even when the fool walks along the road, he lacks sense;
rest: he tells everyone that he is a fool.

firstLine: If the anger of the ruler rises against you,
rest:
do not leave your post,
for calmness can undo great offenses.

firstLine: There is an evil I have seen under the sun—
rest: it is an error that proceeds from a ruler!

firstLine: The fool is set in many high places,
rest: but the rich sit in lowly places.

firstLine: I have even seen slaves riding on horses
rest: and princes walking like slaves on the earth!

firstLine: Accidents Happen—Even to Professionals
rest:
Whoever digs a pit will fall into it.
Whoever breaks through a wall, a snake will bite him.

firstLine: Hard Work and Skill Alone Cannot Succeed—Wisdom is Necessary
rest:
If the ax is blunt but one does not sharpen its edge,
he must exert more effort,
but the advantage of wisdom is it brings success.

firstLine: If the snake bites before the charming,
rest: the snake charmer will not succeed.

firstLine: The Consequences of Foolishness
rest:
The wise man wins favor by the words of his mouth,
but the fool is devoured by his own lips.

firstLine: He begins by saying what is foolish
rest: and ends by uttering what is wicked delusion.

firstLine: The fool talks too much,
rest:
for no one knows what will be.
Who can tell anyone what will happen in the future?

firstLine: The fool is so worn out by a hard day’s work
rest: he cannot even find his way home at night.

firstLine: Woe to you, O land, when your king is a youth
rest: and your princes feast in the morning.

firstLine: Blessed are you, O land, when your king is a son of nobility
rest:
and your princes feast at the proper time—
to gain strength and not to get drunk.

firstLine: Through sloth the roof sinks in,
rest: and through idleness of hands the house leaks.

firstLine: Feasts are held for celebration,
rest:
wine cheers the living,
and money answers everything.

firstLine: Do not curse the king even in your thoughts,
Living in the Light of the Limits of Human Knowledge
rest:
Send out your bread on the water,
for in many days you will find it.

firstLine: Divide your share in seven or in eight,
rest: for you do not know what disaster will happen on the earth.

firstLine: When the clouds are full,
rest:
they empty rain on the earth.
Whether a tree falls to the south or whether it falls to the north,
the place where the tree falls—there it will be.

firstLine: Whoever watches the wind will not sow;
rest: whoever watches the clouds will not reap.

firstLine: Just as you do not know how the path of the wind goes,
rest:
nor how the bones of a fetus form in a mother’s womb,
so you do not know the work of God who makes everything.

firstLine: Sow your seed in the morning,
rest:
and do not let your hands rest in the evening,
for you do not know what will prosper—
whether this or that, or whether both of them alike will succeed.

firstLine: Enjoy Life to the Fullest within the Auspices of the Fear of God
rest:
The light is sweet,
and it is pleasant for the eyes to see the sun.

firstLine: For if a man lives many years,
rest:
let him rejoice in all of them!
Let him remember that the days of the darkness will be many—
all that is coming is vanity!

firstLine: Rejoice, O young man, in your youth,
rest:
and let your heart cheer you in the days of your youth!
Follow the ways of your heart and the sight of your eyes—
but know that God will bring you into judgment for all these things.

firstLine: Banish anxiety from your heart,
rest:
and put away pain from your body,
for youth and vigor are vanity.

firstLine: Advice to the Young: Life is Short and Then You Die
rest:
Remember your Creator in the days of your youth—
before the days of trouble come
and the years draw near when you will say,
“I find no pleasure in them!”

firstLine: Before the sun, the light, the moon, and the stars darken
rest: and the clouds return after the rain.

firstLine: When the guards of the house tremble,
When the doors on the street are shut,
They are afraid of heights,
rest:
and terrors are on the road.
The almond tree blossoms,
and the grasshopper draws itself along, and desire fails
because man goes to his eternal home,
and the mourners go about in the streets.

firstLine: Before the silver cord is snapped
And the dust returns to the earth as it was,
rest: and the breath returns to God who gave it.

firstLine: Motto Restated
rest:
“Vanity of vanity!” says the Teacher.
“Everything is vanity!”

firstLine: Epilogue
rest: The Teacher was full of wisdom, and he taught the people with knowledge. He carefully considered many proverbs and carefully arranged them.

firstLine: Now that all has been heard, here is the final conclusion:
rest:
Fear God and obey his commandments,
for this is the whole duty of man.

firstLine: For God will bring every deed into judgment,
rest: including every secret thing, whether good or evil.

firstLine: Title
rest: The Song of Songs, which is for Solomon.

firstLine: Maiden’s Soliloquy
rest:
May you kiss me passionately with your lips,
for your love is better than wine.

firstLine: As fragrance, your perfumes are delightful;
rest:
your name is poured out perfume;
therefore young women love you.

firstLine: Maiden’s Self-Description
rest:
I am black but beautiful, O maidens of Jerusalem,
like the tents of Kedar, like the curtains of Solomon.

firstLine: Do not gaze at me because I am black,
rest:
because the sun has stared at me.
The sons of my mother were angry with me;
they made me keeper of the vineyards,
but my own “vineyard” I did not keep.

firstLine: Dialogue between Shepherdess and Shepherd
rest:
Tell me, you whom my heart loves,
where do you pasture your flock,
where do your sheep lie down at the noon?
For why should I be like one who is veiled
beside the flocks of your companions?

firstLine: If you do not know, O fairest among women,
rest:
follow the tracks of the flock,
and pasture your little lambs beside the tents of the shepherds.

firstLine: Man’s Poetic Praise of His Beloved
rest:
To a mare among the chariots of Pharaoh,
I compare you, my beloved.

firstLine: Your cheeks are beautiful with ornaments,
rest: your neck with strings of jewels.

firstLine: We will make ornaments of gold for you
rest: with studs of silver.

firstLine: Maiden’s Poetic Praise of Her Beloved
rest:
While the king was on his couch,
my nard gave its fragrance.

firstLine: My beloved is to me a pouch of myrrh,
rest: he spends the night between my breasts.

firstLine: My beloved is to me a cluster of blossoms of henna
rest: in the vineyards of En Gedi.

firstLine: Mutual Admiration
the beams of our house are cedar;
rest: our rafter is cypress.

firstLine: Dialogue between Maiden and Her Beloved
rest:
I am a rose of Sharon,
a lily of the valleys.

firstLine: Like a lily among the thorns,
rest: so is my love among the maidens.

firstLine: As an apple tree among the trees of the forest,
rest:
so is my beloved among the young men.
In his shade I sat down with delight,
and his fruit was sweet to my palate.

firstLine: Banquet Hall of Love
rest:
He brought me to the house of the wine,
and his intention was love toward me.

firstLine: Sustain me with the raisins,
rest:
refresh me with the apples,
for I am lovesick.

firstLine: Double Refrain: Embrace and Adjuration
rest:
His left hand is under my head,
and his right hand embraces me.

firstLine: I adjure you, O maidens of Jerusalem,
rest:
by the gazelles or by the does of the field,
do not arouse or awaken love until it pleases!

firstLine: Rendezvous in the Countryside
rest:
The voice of my beloved!
Look! Here he comes leaping upon the mountains,
bounding over the hills!

firstLine: My beloved answered and said to me,
rest: “Arise, my beloved! Come, my beauty!

firstLine: The blossoms appear in the land;
rest:
the time of singing has arrived;
the voice of the turtledove is heard in our land.

firstLine: The fig tree puts forth her figs,
rest:
and the vines are in blossom; they give fragrance.
Arise, my beloved! Come, my beauty!”

firstLine: My dove, in the clefts of the rock,
rest:
in the secluded place in the mountain,
Let me see your face,
let me hear your voice;
for your voice is sweet and your face is lovely.

firstLine: Catch for us the foxes,
rest:
the little foxes destroying vineyards,
for our vineyards are in blossom!

firstLine: Poetic Refrain(s)
rest:
My beloved belongs to me and I belong to him;
he pastures his flock among the lilies.

firstLine: Until the day breathes and the shadows flee,
rest:
turn, my beloved!
Be like a gazelle or young stag on the cleft mountains.

firstLine: Now I will arise, and I will go about in the city,
Scarcely had I passed by them
rest:
when I found him whom my heart loves.
I held him and I would not let him go
until I brought him to the house of my mother,
into the bedroom chamber of she who conceived me.

firstLine: Adjuration Refrain
rest:
I adjure you, O maidens of Jerusalem,
by the gazelles or by the does of the field,
do not arouse or awaken love until it pleases!

firstLine: Royal Wedding Procession
rest:
What is this coming up from the desert
like a column of smoke,
perfumed with myrrh and frankincense
from all the fragrant powders of the merchant?

firstLine: All of them wield swords;
rest:
they are trained in warfare,
each with his sword at his thigh
to guard against terror in the night.

firstLine: King Solomon made for himself a sedan chair
rest: from the wood of Lebanon.

firstLine: He made its column of silver, its back of gold, its seat of purple;
rest: its interior is inlaid with leather by the maidens of Jerusalem.

firstLine: Come out and look, O maidens of Zion, at King Solomon,
rest:
at the crown with which his mother crowned him
on the day of his wedding,
on the day of the joy of his heart!

firstLine: Groom’s Praise of His Bride
rest:
Oh my! You are beautiful, my beloved!
Oh my! You are beautiful!
Your eyes are doves
from behind your veil.
Your hair is like a flock of goats
that move down from the mountains of Gilead.

firstLine: Your teeth are like a flock of shorn ewes
rest:
that came up from the washing,
all of them bearing twins,
and there is none bereaved among them.

firstLine: Your lips are like a thread of crimson,
rest:
and your mouth is lovely.
Your temple is like pomegranate
from behind your veil.

firstLine: Your neck is like the tower of David,
Your two breasts are like two fawns,
rest: twins of a gazelle that feed among the lilies.

firstLine: Until the day breathes and the shadows flee,
rest:
I will go to the mountain of the myrrh,
to the hill of the frankincense.

firstLine: The Mountains and Fragrance of Lebanon
Your lips drip nectar, my bride;
rest:
honey and milk are under your lips;
the scent of your garments is like the scent of Lebanon.

firstLine: The Locked Garden of Delights Is Unlocked
rest:
A garden locked is my sister bride,
a spring enclosed, a fountain sealed.

firstLine: Your shoots are an orchard of pomegranates with choice fruit,
rest: henna with nard;

firstLine: nard and saffron, calamus and cinnamon spice with all trees of frankincense,
rest: myrrh and aloes with all chief spices.

firstLine: A garden fountain, a well of living water,
rest: flowing (streams) from Lebanon.

firstLine: I have come to my garden, my sister bride,
rest:
I have gathered my myrrh with my spice,
I have eaten my honeycomb with my honey,
I have drunk my wine with my milk!
Eat, O friends! Drink and become drunk with love!

firstLine: Maiden’s Dream: Seeking and Not Finding
rest:
I was asleep but my heart was awake.
A sound! My beloved knocking!
“Open to me, my sister, my beloved,
my dove, my perfect one!
For my head is full of dew,
my hair drenched from the moist night air.”

firstLine: My beloved thrust his hand into the opening,
rest: and my inmost yearned for him.

firstLine: I myself arose to open to my beloved;
rest:
my hands dripped with myrrh,
my fingers with liquid myrrh
upon the handles of the bolt.

firstLine: I opened myself to my beloved,
The sentinels making rounds in the city found me;
Adjuration Refrain
rest:
I adjure you, O maidens of Jerusalem,
if you find my beloved, what will you tell him?
Tell him that I am lovesick!

firstLine: Maiden’s Praise of Her Beloved
rest:
How is your beloved better than another lover,
O most beautiful among women?
How is your beloved better than another lover,
that you adjure us thus?

firstLine: My beloved is radiant and ruddy,
rest: distinguished among ten thousand.

firstLine: His head is gold, refined gold;
rest: his locks are wavy, black as a raven.

firstLine: His eyes are like doves beside springs of water,
rest: bathed in milk, set like mounted jewels.

firstLine: His cheeks are like beds of spice, a tower of fragrances;
rest: his lips are lilies dripping liquid myrrh.

firstLine: His arms are rods of gold engraved with jewels;
rest: his belly is polished ivory covered with sapphires.

firstLine: His legs are columns of alabaster, set on bases of gold;
rest: his appearance is like Lebanon, choice as its cedars.

firstLine: His mouth is sweet,
Where has your beloved gone,
rest:
O most beautiful among women?
Where has your beloved turned
that we may seek him with you?

firstLine: My beloved has gone down to his garden,
rest:
to the garden bed of the spice,
to pasture his flock and to gather lilies in the garden.

firstLine: Mutual Possession Refrain
rest:
I belong to my beloved and he belongs to me;
he pastures his flock among the lilies.

firstLine: Solomon’s Praise of His Beloved
rest:
You are beautiful, my beloved, as Tirzah,
lovely as Jerusalem,
overwhelming as an army with banners.

firstLine: Turn away your eyes from before me,
rest:
for they overwhelm me.
Your hair is like a flock of the goats
that moves down from Gilead.

firstLine: Your teeth are like a flock of the ewes
rest:
that have come up from the washing,
all of them bearing twins,
and there is none bereaved among them.

firstLine: Your cheeks behind your veil
rest: are like halves of a pomegranate.

firstLine: The Maiden’s Beauty Is without Peer
rest:
Sixty queens there are, eighty concubines,
and maidens beyond number.

firstLine: My dove, she is the one;
“Who is this that looks down like the dawn,
rest:
beautiful as the moon,
bright as the sun,
overwhelming as an army with banners?”

firstLine: The Journey to the Valley
rest:
I went down to the orchard of the walnut trees
to look at the blossoms of the valley,
to see whether the vines have sprouted,
whether the pomegranates have blossomed.

firstLine: I did not know my heart set me
rest: in a chariot of my princely people.

firstLine: Solomon’s Praise of His Dancing Maiden
rest:
How beautiful are your feet in sandals,
O royal princess!
The curves of your thighs are like jewels,
the work of the hands of a craftsman.

firstLine: Your navel is a round wine-mixing bowl
rest:
that does not lack mixed wine!
Your belly is a heap of wheat
encircled with lilies.

firstLine: Your two breasts are like two fawns,
rest: twins of a gazelle.

firstLine: Your neck is like a tower of ivory;
rest:
your eyes are pools in Heshbon at the gate of Beth Rabbim.
Your nose is like the tower of Lebanon
looking out over Damascus.

firstLine: Your head crowns you like Carmel;
rest:
the flowing locks of your head are like purple tapestry;
a king is held captive in the tresses!

firstLine: How beautiful you are and how pleasant,
rest: O loved one in the delights!

firstLine: Your stature is like the palm tree,
rest: and your breasts are like clusters.

firstLine: I say, “I will climb up the palm tree;
rest:
I will lay hold of its fruit clusters.”
Let your breasts be pleasing like clusters of the vine
and the scent of your breath like the apples.

firstLine: Your palate is like the best wine that goes down for my beloved,
rest: smoothly gliding over my lips and teeth.

firstLine: Mutual Possession Refrain
rest:
I belong to my beloved,
and he desires me!

firstLine: Rendezvous in the Countryside
rest:
Come, my beloved, let us go out to the countryside;
let us spend the night in the villages.

firstLine: Let us rise early to go to the vineyards;
The mandrakes give off their fragrance,
rest:
and over our doorway is every kind of delicious fruit;
both fresh and dried fruit I have stored up for you, O my beloved.

firstLine: Maiden’s Fanciful Wish
rest:
How I wish that you were my little brother,
who nursed upon my mother’s breasts!
If I met you outside, I would kiss you,
and no one would despise me!

firstLine: I would surely bring you to the house of my mother,
Double Refrain: Embrace and Adjuration
rest:
His left hand is under my head,
and his right hand embraces me.

firstLine: I adjure you, O maidens of Jerusalem,
rest: do not arouse or awaken love until it pleases!

firstLine: Up from the Wilderness and under the Apple Tree
The Nature of Genuine Romantic Love
Many waters cannot quench love;
rest:
rivers cannot sweep it away.
If a man were to give all the wealth of his house for love,
he would be utterly scorned.

firstLine: Maiden’s Virtuous Chastity and Voluptuous Beauty
rest:
We have a little sister,
and she does not yet have any breasts.
What should we do for our sister
on the day when she is betrothed?

firstLine: If she is a wall,
I was a wall, and my breasts were like the towers,
rest: so my betrothed viewed me with great delight.

firstLine: Solomon’s Vineyard and the Maiden’s Gift
My own “vineyard” belongs to me;
rest:
the “thousand” are for you, O Solomon,
and “two hundred” for those who tend its fruit.

firstLine: Closing Words of Mutual Love
rest:
O you who dwell in the garden,
my companions are listening to your voice.
Let me hear it!

firstLine: Superscription
rest: The vision of Isaiah son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.

firstLine: Rebellious Judah
rest:
Hear, heavens,
and listen, earth,
for Yahweh has spoken:
“I reared children
and I brought them up,
but they rebelled against me.

firstLine: An ox knows its owner
Ah, sinful nation,
rest:
a people heavy with iniquity,
offspring of evildoers,
children who deal corruptly.
They have forsaken Yahweh;
they have despised the holy one of Israel.
They are estranged and gone backward.

firstLine: From the sole of the foot and up to the head
rest:
there is no health in it;
bruise and sore and bleeding wound have not been cleansed,
and they have not been bound up
and not softened with the oil.

firstLine: Your country is desolate,
And the daughter of Zion is left like a booth in a vineyard,
rest:
like a shelter in a cucumber field,
like a city that is besieged.

firstLine: If Yahweh of hosts had not left us survivors,
rest:
we would have been as few as Sodom,
we would have become like Gomorrah.

firstLine: When you come to appear before me,
rest:
who asked for this from your hand:
you trampling my courts?

firstLine: You must not continue to bring offerings of futility,
Your new moons and your appointed festivals my soul hates;
rest:
they have become to me like a burden,
I am not able to bear them.

firstLine: And when you stretch out your hands,
rest:
I will hide my eyes from you;
even though you make many prayers,
I will not be listening.
Your hands are full of blood.

firstLine: “Come now, and let us argue,” says Yahweh.
rest:
“Even though your sins are like scarlet, they will be white like snow;
even though they are red like crimson, they shall become like wool.

firstLine: If you are willing and you are obedient,
rest: you shall eat the good of the land.

firstLine: Purifying Jerusalem
rest:
How has a faithful city become like a whore?
Full of justice, righteousness lodged in her, but now murderers.

firstLine: Your silver has become as dross;
rest: Your wine is diluted with waters.

firstLine: Your princes are rebels
rest:
and companions of thieves.
Every one loves a bribe
and runs after gifts.
They do not defend the orphan
and the legal dispute of the widow does not come before them.

firstLine: Therefore, the declaration of the Lord Yahweh of hosts, the Mighty One of Israel:
rest:
“Ah, I will be relieved of my enemies,
and I will avenge myself on my foes.

firstLine: And I will turn my hand against you;
rest:
I will purify your dross like lye,
and I will remove all of your tin.

firstLine: And I will restore your judges, as at the first,
rest:
and your counselors, as at the beginning.
After this you will be called the city of righteousness,
faithful city.

firstLine: Zion will be redeemed by justice,
rest: and those of her who repent, by righteousness.

firstLine: But the destruction of rebels and sinners shall be together,
rest: and those who forsake Yahweh will perish.

firstLine: For you will be ashamed of the oaks in which you delighted,
rest: and you will be disgraced because of the gardens that you have chosen.

firstLine: For you shall be like an oak withering its leaves,
rest: and like a garden where there is no water for her.

firstLine: And the strong man shall become like tinder,
rest:
and his work like a spark.
And both of them shall burn together,
and there is not one to quench them.”

firstLine: The Mountain of Yahweh
rest: The word that Isaiah son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem:

firstLine: And it shall happen in the future of the days
He shall judge between the nations
rest:
and he shall arbitrate for many peoples.
They shall beat their swords into ploughshares
and their spears into pruning hooks.
A nation shall not lift up a sword against a nation,
and they shall not learn war again.

firstLine: The Day of Yahweh
rest: House of Jacob, come and let us walk in the light of Yahweh.

firstLine: For you have forsaken your people, house of Jacob,
rest:
because they are full from the east,
and of soothsayers like the Philistines,
and they make alliances with the offspring of foreigners.

firstLine: And its land is filled with silver and gold,
Its land is filled with idols;
rest:
they bow down to the work of their hands,
to what they made with their fingers.

firstLine: So humanity is humbled;
rest:
everyone is humbled,
and you must not forgive them.

firstLine: Enter into the rock
rest:
and hide yourself in the dust
from the presence of the terror of Yahweh
and from the glory of his majesty.

firstLine: The haughty eyes of humanity will be brought low,
rest:
and the pride of everyone will be humbled,
and Yahweh alone will be exalted on that day.

firstLine: For there is a day for Yahweh of hosts
rest:
against all of the proud and the lofty
and against all that is lifted up and humble,

firstLine: and against all the lofty and lifted up cedars of Lebanon,
rest: and against all the large trees of Bashan,

firstLine: and against all the high mountains,
rest: and against all the lofty hills,

firstLine: and against every kind of high tower,
rest: and against every kind of fortified wall,

firstLine: and against all the ships of Tarshish,
rest: and against all the ships of desire.

firstLine: And the haughtiness of the people shall be humbled,
rest:
and the pride of everyone shall be brought low,
and Yahweh alone will be exalted on that day.

firstLine: and they will enter into the caves of the rocks
rest:
and into the holes of the ground
from the presence of the terror of Yahweh
and from the glory of his majesty
when he rises to terrify the earth.

firstLine: On that day humanity will throw away its idols of silver
rest:
and its idols of gold,
which they made for it to worship,
to the rodents and to the bats—

firstLine: to enter into the crevices of the rocks
rest:
and into the clefts of the crags
from the presence of the terror of Yahweh
and from the glory of his majesty,
when he rises to terrify the earth.

firstLine: Turn away from humanity,
rest:
who has breath in its nostrils,
for by what is it esteemed?

firstLine: Leaders of Judah and Jerusalem
rest:
For look, the Lord Yahweh of hosts is removing every source of support
from Jerusalem and from Judah:
all of the supplies of bread
and all of the supplies of water,

firstLine: mighty warrior and man of war,
rest:
judge and prophet,
and diviner and elder,

firstLine: captain of fifty and the honorable men of rank,
rest: and counselor and skillful magicians and skillful enchanter.

firstLine: And I will make boys their princes,
rest: and children shall rule over them.

firstLine: And the people will be oppressed by each other
rest:
and a man by his neighbor.
The boy will act arrogantly toward the elder,
and the dishonorable toward the honorable.

firstLine: Indeed, a man will seize his brother
rest:
in the house of his father:
“You have a cloak;
you shall be a leader for us,
and this heap of ruins shall be under your hand!”

firstLine: He will lift up his voice on that day, saying,
rest:
“I will not be a healer;
in my house there is no bread
and there is no cloak.
You shall not make me the leader of the people!”

firstLine: For Jerusalem has stumbled,
rest:
and Judah has fallen
because their speech and their deeds are against Yahweh,
defying the eyes of his glory.

firstLine: The look on their faces testifies against them
rest:
and they declare their sin like Sodom;
they do not hide it.
Woe to their soul!
For they have dealt out evil to themselves.

firstLine: Tell the innocent that it is good
rest: for they shall eat the fruit of their deeds.

firstLine: My people—children are their oppressors,
rest:
and women rule over them.
My people, your leaders are misleading you,
and they confuse the course of your paths.

firstLine: Yahweh takes his stand to conduct a legal case
rest: and takes his stand to judge the peoples.

firstLine: Why do you crush my people
rest:
and grind the face of the poor?”
declares the Lord Yahweh of hosts.

firstLine: The Pride of Jerusalem’s Women
rest:
And Yahweh said: “Because the daughters of Zion are haughty,
and they walk with outstretched neck,
and they give flirting glances with their eyes,
mincing along as they go,
and with their feet they rattle their bangles,

firstLine: the Lord will make the heads of the daughters of Zion scabby,
rest: and Yahweh will lay their foreheads bare.”

firstLine: In that day the Lord will take away the finery of the anklets
rest: and the headbands and the crescent necklaces,

firstLine: the headdresses and the armlets and the sashes,
rest: and the perfume boxes and the amulets,

firstLine: the festal robes and the mantles,
rest: and the cloaks and the handbags,

firstLine: and the mirrors and the linen garments,
rest: and the turbans and the wraps.

firstLine: And this shall happen: There will be
rest:
a stench instead of perfume,
and a rope instead of a sash,
and baldness instead of a well-set hairdo,
and a clothing wrap of sackcloth instead of a rich robe,
branding instead of beauty.

firstLine: Your men shall fall by the sword,
rest: and your warriors in battle.

firstLine: And her gates shall lament and mourn,
rest:
and she shall be banished;
she shall sit upon the ground.

firstLine: And seven women shall grasp at one man on that day, saying,
rest:
“We will eat our own bread,
and we will wear our own clothing;
only let us be called by your name!
Take away our disgrace!”

firstLine: The Glory of the Branch of Yahweh
rest:
On that day the branch of Yahweh shall become beautiful and glorious,
and the fruit of the land shall become the pride and glory of the survivors of Israel.

firstLine: And this shall happen: He who is left in Zion
rest:
and he who remains in Jerusalem will be called holy,
everyone written for life in Jerusalem,

firstLine: when the Lord has washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion
rest:
and cleansed the blood of Jerusalem from her midst
by a spirit of judgment
and by a spirit of burning.

firstLine: Then Yahweh will create over all of the site of Mount Zion
rest:
and over her assembly a cloud by day
and smoke and the brightness of flaming fire by night.
Indeed, over all the glory there will be a canopy,

firstLine: and it will be a shelter for shade from the heat by day,
rest: and a refuge and a hiding place from rainstorm and from rain.

firstLine: The Song of the Vineyard
rest:
Let me sing for my beloved
a song of my love concerning his vineyard:
My beloved had a vineyard on a fertile hill.

firstLine: And he dug it and cleared it of stones,
rest:
and he planted it with choice vines,
and he built a watchtower in the middle of it,
and he even hewed out a wine vat in it,
and he waited for it to yield grapes—
but it yielded wild grapes.

firstLine: And now, inhabitants of Jerusalem
rest: and men of Judah, judge between me and my vineyard.

firstLine: And I will make it a wasteland;
rest:
it shall not be pruned and hoed,
and it shall be overgrown with briers and thornbushes.
And concerning the clouds, I will command them not to send rain down upon it.

firstLine: For the vineyard of Yahweh of hosts is the house of Israel,
rest:
and the man of Judah is the plantation of his delight.
And he waited for justice,
but look! Bloodshed!
For righteousness,
but look! A cry of distress!

firstLine: Woes on the Wicked
rest:
Ah! Those who join house with house,
they join field together with field
until there is no place
and you are caused to dwell alone in the midst of the land.

firstLine: Yahweh of hosts said in my ears:
rest:
Surely many houses shall become a desolation,
large and beautiful ones without inhabitant.

firstLine: For ten acres of vineyard shall yield one bath,
rest: and the seed of a homer will yield an ephah.

firstLine: And there will be lyre and harp,
rest:
tambourine and flute,
and wine at their feasts,
but they do not look at the deeds of Yahweh,
and they do not see the work of his hands.

firstLine: Therefore my people will go into exile without knowledge,
rest:
and their nobles will be men of hunger,
and their multitude is parched with thirst.

firstLine: Therefore Sheol has enlarged its throat,
rest:
and it has opened wide its mouth without limit,
and her nobles will go down, and her multitude,
her tumult and those who revel in her.

firstLine: And humankind is bowed down,
rest:
and man is brought low,
and the eyes of the haughty are humiliated.

firstLine: But Yahweh of hosts is exalted by justice,
rest: and the holy God shows himself holy by righteousness.

firstLine: And then the lambs will graze as in their pasture,
rest: and fatlings, kids will eat among the sites of ruins.

firstLine: those who say,
rest:
“Let him make haste;
let him hurry his work
so that we may see it
and let it draw near
and let the plan of the holy one of Israel come
so that we may know it!”

firstLine: Those who acquit the guilty because of a bribe
rest: and remove the justice of the innocent from him.

firstLine: Therefore as the tongue of fire devours the stubble,
rest:
and dry grass sinks down in the flame,
so their root will become like the stench,
and their blossom will go up like the dust.
For they have rejected the instruction of Yahweh of hosts,
and they have treated the word of the holy one of Israel with contempt.

firstLine: Therefore Yahweh’s wrath was kindled against his people,
rest:
and he stretched out his hand against them and struck them,
and the mountains quaked,
and their corpses were like refuse in the middle of the streets.
Yahweh’s Outstretched Hand
In all of this his anger has not turned back,
and still his hand is stretched out.

firstLine: And he will raise a signal for a nation from afar,
rest:
and he will whistle for it from the end of the earth.
And look! It comes quickly, swiftly!

firstLine: None is weary,
rest:
and none among him stumbles;
none slumbers and none sleeps.
And no loincloth on his waist is opened,
and no thong of his sandals is drawn away.

firstLine: Whose arrows are sharp,
rest:
and all of his bows are bent.
The hoofs of his horses are reckoned like flint,
and his wheels like the storm wind.

firstLine: His roaring is like the lion,
rest:
and he roars like young lions.
And he growls and seizes his prey,
and he carries it off,
and not one can rescue it.

firstLine: And he will roar over him on that day
rest:
like the roaring of the sea,
and if one looks to the land, look! Darkness! Distress!
And the light grows dark with its clouds.

firstLine: Isaiah’s Commission
rest: In the year of the death of Uzziah the king, I saw the Lord sitting on a high and raised throne, and the hem of his robe was filling the temple.

firstLine: And the one called to the other and said,
rest:
“Holy, holy, holy is Yahweh of hosts!
The whole earth is full of his glory.”

firstLine: And he touched my mouth, and he said,
rest:
“Look! This has touched your lips
and has removed your guilt,
and your sin is annulled.”

firstLine: Then I heard the voice of the Lord saying,
rest:
“Whom shall I send?
And who will go for us?”
And I said,
“I am here!
Send me!”

firstLine: And he said, “Go and say to this people,
rest:
‘Keep on listening and do not comprehend!
And keep on looking and do not understand!’

firstLine: Make the heart of this people insensitive,
rest:
and make its ears unresponsive,
and shut its eyes
so that it may not look with its eyes
and listen with its ears
and comprehend with its mind
and turn back, and it may be healed for him.”

firstLine: and Yahweh sends the people far away,
rest: and the abandonment is great in the midst of the land.

firstLine: And even if only a tenth part remain, again she will be destroyed
rest:
like a terebinth or like an oak,
which although felled, a tree stump remains in them.
The seed of holiness will be her tree stump.”

firstLine: The Sign to Ahaz
rest: This happened in the days of Ahaz, son of Jotham, son of Uzziah, king of Judah. Rezin, king of Aram, and Pekah, son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up to Jerusalem for warfare against it, but he was not able to fight against it.

firstLine: That Day
rest: “Yahweh will bring on you and on your people and on the house of your ancestor days that have not come since the day Ephraim departed from Judah: the king of Assyria.”

firstLine: Signs of the Assyrian Invasion
rest: Then Yahweh said to me, “Take yourself a large tablet and write on it with a common stylus pen: Maher-Halal-Hash-Baz.

firstLine: Shiloah Waters and Euphrates Flood
rest: And Yahweh continued to speak to me again, saying,

firstLine: And he will sweep into Judah;
rest:
he will overflow and he will flood up to the neck.
He will reach, and he will spread his wings out over your entire land, God with us.”

firstLine: Wait for Yahweh
rest:
For Yahweh said this to me while his hand weighed heavily on me,
and he warned me not to walk in the way of this people, saying,

firstLine: “You must not call conspiracy everything that this people calls conspiracy,
rest: and you must not share its fear, and you must not be in dread.

firstLine: You shall regard Yahweh of hosts as holy,
rest: and he is your fear, and he is your dread.

firstLine: And he will become like a sanctuary and a stumbling-stone,
rest:
and like a stumbling-rock for the two houses of Israel,
like a trap and a snare for the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

firstLine: And many shall stumble among them,
rest:
and they shall fall and they shall be broken,
and they shall be ensnared and they shall be caught.”

firstLine: Bind up the testimony;
rest: seal the teaching among my disciples.

firstLine: And I will wait for Yahweh,
rest:
who hides his face from the house of Jacob,
and I will await him.

firstLine: New Light: The Birth of a King
rest:
But there will be no gloom for those who were in distress.
In former times he treated the land of Zebulun and Naphtali with contempt, but in the future he will honor the way of the sea beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the nations.

firstLine: The people who walked in darkness have seen a great light;
rest: light has shined on those who lived in a land of darkness.

firstLine: You have made the nation numerous;
rest:
you have not made the joy great.
They rejoice in your presence as with joy at the harvest,
as they rejoice when they divide plunder.

firstLine: For you have shattered the yoke of its burden
rest:
and the stick of its shoulder,
the rod of its oppressor, on the day of Midian.

firstLine: For every boot that marches and shakes the earth
rest:
and garment rolled in blood
will be for burning—fire fuel.

firstLine: For a child has been born for us;
rest:
a son has been given to us.
And the dominion will be on his shoulder,
and his name is called Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God,
Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace.

firstLine: His dominion will grow continually,
rest:
and to peace there will be no end
on the throne of David and over his kingdom,
to establish it and sustain it
with justice and righteousness
now and forever.
The zeal of Yahweh of hosts will do this.

firstLine: Yahweh’s Anger against Arrogance
rest:
The Lord has sent out a word against Jacob,
and it fell on Israel.

firstLine: And all of the people knew it,
rest:
Ephraim and the inhabitants of Samaria
in pride and arrogance of heart, saying,

firstLine: “The bricks have fallen, but we will build with dressed stone.
rest: The sycamore-fig trees were felled, but we will replace them with cedars.”

firstLine: So Yahweh strengthened the adversaries of Rezin against him,
rest: and he provoked his enemies—

firstLine: Aram from the east
rest:
and Philistines from the west—
and they devoured Israel with the whole mouth.
He has not turned away his anger in all of this,
and his hand is still stretched out.

firstLine: And the people did not turn to the one who struck it,
rest: and they did not seek Yahweh of hosts.

firstLine: So Yahweh cut off head and tail from Israel,
rest: palm branch and reed in one day.

firstLine: Elders and the respectable are the head,
rest: and prophets who teach lies are the tail.

firstLine: And the leaders of this people were misleading them,
rest: and those who were led were confused.

firstLine: Therefore the Lord did not rejoice over its young men,
rest:
and he did not have compassion on its orphans and widows,
for everyone was godless and an evildoer,
and every mouth was speaking folly.
In all of this his anger did not turn away,
and still his hand is stretched out.

firstLine: For wickedness burned like fire;
rest:
it consumed brier and thorn.
And it kindled the thickets of the forest,
and they swirled upward in a column of smoke.

firstLine: The land was burned through the wrath of Yahweh of hosts,
rest:
and the people became like fire fuel.
People had no compassion toward each other.

firstLine: They devoured on the right but still were hungry
rest:
and devoured on the left but they were not satisfied.
Each one devoured the flesh of his arm,

firstLine: Manasseh devoured Ephraim, and Ephraim Manasseh;
rest:
together they were against Judah.
In all of this his anger has not turned away,
and still his hand is stretched out.

firstLine: Woes on the Wicked
rest:
Ah! Those who decree decrees of evil,
and writers who have written harm,

firstLine: to guide the needy away from legal claims,
And what will you do at the day of punishment,
rest:
and at calamity? It comes from afar!
To whom will you flee for help,
and where will you leave your wealth,

firstLine: save that they bow down under the prisoners
rest:
and fall under the slain?
In all of this his anger has not turned away,
and still his hand is stretched out.

firstLine: Judgment on Assyria’s Arrogance
rest:
Ah! Assyria, the rod of my anger,
and a staff is in their hand: my wrath!

firstLine: I send him against a godless nation,
rest:
and I command him against the people of my wrath,
to capture spoil
and to carry off plunder,
and to make them a trampling place,
like the clay of the streets.

firstLine: But he does not think this,
rest:
and his heart does not plan this.
For it is in his heart to destroy
and to cut off not a few nations.

firstLine: As my hand has reached to the kingdoms of the idols
rest: —and their images were greater than those of Jerusalem and Samaria—

firstLine: shall I not do to Jerusalem and its idols
rest: what I have done to Samaria and her idols?”

firstLine: For he says,
rest:
“I have done it by the strength of my hand
and by my wisdom, for I have understanding,
and I have removed the boundaries of peoples,
and I have plundered their stores,
and like a bull I have brought down the inhabitants.

firstLine: And my hand has found, like a nest, the wealth of the peoples,
rest:
and like the gathering of forsaken eggs, I myself have gathered all the earth.
And there was no fluttering wing or open mouth or chirp.”

firstLine: Does the ax boast against the one who cuts with it,
rest:
or the saw magnify itself against the one who moves it to and fro?
As if a rod should move the one who lifts it!
As if a staff should lift up that which is not wood!

firstLine: Therefore the Lord, Yahweh of hosts, will send leanness among his sturdy warriors,
rest: and a burning like the burning of fire will burn under his glory.

firstLine: And the light of Israel will become like a fire,
rest:
and his holy one like a flame,
and it will burn and devour his thorns and briers in one day.

firstLine: And he will destroy the glory of his forest and orchard completely,
rest: and it will be like the wasting away of one who is sick.

firstLine: And the rest of the trees of his forest will be a small number,
rest: and a boy can write them down.

firstLine: The Return of the Remnant
rest:
And this shall happen: on that day, the remnant of Israel and the survivors of the house of Jacob will not continue to lean on the one who struck it
but will lean on Yahweh, the holy one of Israel, in truth.

firstLine: A remnant will return—
rest: the remnant of Jacob—to the mighty God.

firstLine: For though your people Israel was like the sand of the sea,
rest:
only a remnant of it will return.
Annihilation is determined,
overflowing with righteousness.

firstLine: For the Lord Yahweh of hosts is about to make a complete destruction
rest: and a determined end in the midst of all the earth.

firstLine: Therefore thus says the Lord Yahweh of hosts:
rest:
“My people who live in Zion,
you must not be afraid of Assyria.
It beats you with the rod,
and it lifts up its staff against you as the Egyptians did.

firstLine: My indignation will come to an end in just a very little while,
rest: and my anger will be directed to their destruction.”

firstLine: And Yahweh of hosts is going to swing a whip against him,
And this shall happen: on that day,
rest:
he will remove his burden from your shoulder
and his yoke from your neck,
and a yoke will be destroyed because of fat.

firstLine: He has come to Aiath,
rest:
he has passed through Migron;
at Micmash he deposited his baggage.

firstLine: They crossed over the pass;
Daughter of Gallim, cry out with your voice;
rest:
Laishah, listen!
Anathoth is poor.

firstLine: This day taking a stand at Nob,
rest:
he will shake his fist at the mountain of the daughter of Zion,
at the hill of Jerusalem.

firstLine: And he will cut down the thickets of the forest with the axe,
rest: and Lebanon will fall by the mighty one.

firstLine: The Branch’s Righteous Reign
rest:
And a shoot will come out from the stump of Jesse,
and a branch from its roots will bear fruit.

firstLine: And the spirit of Yahweh shall rest on him—
rest:
a spirit of wisdom and understanding,
a spirit of counsel and might,
a spirit of knowledge and the fear of Yahweh.

firstLine: But he shall judge the poor with righteousness,
rest:
and he shall decide for the needy of the earth with rectitude.
And he shall strike the earth with the rod of his mouth,
and he shall kill the wicked person with the breath of his lips.

firstLine: And righteousness shall be the belt around his waist,
rest: and faithfulness the belt around his loins.

firstLine: And a wolf shall stay with a lamb,
rest:
and a leopard shall lie down with a kid,
and a calf and a lion and a fatling together
as a small boy leads them.

firstLine: And a cow and a bear shall graze;
rest:
their young shall lie down together.
And a lion shall eat straw like the cattle.

firstLine: And an infant shall play over a serpent’s hole,
rest: and a toddler shall put his hand on a viper’s hole.

firstLine: They will not injure and they will not destroy on all of my holy mountain,
rest:
for the earth will be full of the knowledge of Yahweh,
as the waters cover the sea.

firstLine: And this shall happen on that day:
rest:
the nations shall inquire of the root of Jesse,
which shall be standing as a signal to the peoples,
and his resting place shall be glorious.

firstLine: The Regathered Remnant
rest:
And this shall happen on that day:
The Lord will again extend his hand a second time
to acquire the remnant of his people that is left,
from Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Cush, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, and the coastlands of the sea,

firstLine: And the jealousy of Ephraim shall depart,
rest:
and the enemies of Judah shall be cut off.
Ephraim shall not be jealous of Judah,
and Judah shall not be an enemy of Ephraim.

firstLine: And Yahweh will divide the tongue of the sea of Egypt,
So there shall be a highway from Assyria for the remnant of his people that remains,
rest: as there was for Israel when it went up from the land of Egypt.

firstLine: A Song of Thanksgiving
rest:
And you will say on that day,
“I will give you thanks, Yahweh,
for though you were angry with me,
your anger turned away,
and you comforted me.

firstLine: And you will say on that day,
Sing praises to Yahweh, for he has done a glorious thing;
rest: this is known in all the earth.

firstLine: Inhabitant of Zion, shout out and sing for joy,
rest: for the holy one of Israel is great in your midst.”

firstLine: An Oracle against Babylon
rest: The oracle of Babylon that Isaiah son of Amoz saw:

firstLine: Raise a signal on a bare hill,
rest:
lift up your voice to them;
wave the hand and may they enter the gateways of the noblemen.

firstLine: I myself I have commanded my consecrated ones,
rest:
I have also summoned my mighty warriors concerning my anger,
the ones who exalt over my majesty.

firstLine: A sound, a noise is on the mountains,
rest:
the likeness of many people!
A sound of the roar of the kingdoms,
of nations gathering!
Yahweh of hosts is mustering an army for battle.

firstLine: They are coming from a distant land,
Wail, for the day of Yahweh is near;
rest: it will come like destruction from Shaddai!

firstLine: Therefore all hands will grow slack,
rest: and every human heart will melt,

firstLine: For the stars of the heavens and their constellations will not flash forth their light;
rest:
the sun will keep back when it comes out,
and the moon will not cause its light to shine.

firstLine: And I will punish the world for its evil
rest:
and the wicked for their iniquity.
And I will put an end to the pride of the arrogant,
and I will bring the haughtiness of tyrants low.

firstLine: I will make humanity more rare than gold
rest: and humankind more than the gold of Ophir.

firstLine: Therefore I will make the heavens tremble,
rest:
and the earth will quake from its place
because of the wrath of Yahweh of hosts,
and in the day his anger burns.

firstLine: And this shall happen:
rest:
like a hunted gazelle or sheep with none to gather them,
they will each turn to his own people,
and they will each flee to his own land.

firstLine: Everyone who is found will be pierced through,
rest: and everyone who is carried away will fall by the sword.

firstLine: And their children will be dashed into pieces before their eyes;
rest: their houses will be plundered, and their wives will be raped.

firstLine: It will not be inhabited forever,
But wild animals will lie down there,
rest:
and their houses will be full of howling creatures,
and the daughters of ostriches will live there,
and goats will dance there.

firstLine: And hyenas will answer in its palaces,
The Restoration of Israel
rest:
But Yahweh will have compassion on Jacob,
and he will again choose Israel
and set them on their land,
and the immigrant will join himself to them,
